column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Like when looking at an optical illusion image and seeing black dots between white lines on a grid; I know that I was just seeing fleeting artefacts in my peripheral vision.
column10: It reminded me of looking at an optical illusion image (the grid illusion) where you can see fleeting black circles in the corners of the grid even though there are none. My peripheral vision was activating and showing me spinning red circles, or a red circle in the very center, but only during the flash and they would instantly change or disappear. If I looked up or down slightly, I could see bars of red on the top or bottom of the screen, same for left and right, and I would see no circles or illusion in the center. If I looked in the center of the screen, I would see a bright red circle, surrounded by flashing black/red circles moving around it in a circular fashion (all around the center point). These images would not persist and I could not focus on them. If I tried to focus on any of the illusionary circles, they would disappear. Often, the screen would once again seem to simply show red and black flickers across the entire screen. I did not see any recognizable complex images such as buildings, scenery, faces, animals, movie scenes, or anything else. I do not believe that I was experiencing imagination, just optical illusions. It was not an enjoyable experience, but I felt no overwhelming discomfort, else I would have stopped the experiment. I do not see anything differently now that I have completed the experiment.

column10:
42" 4K monitor from about 24"... All shapes in circular pattern mostly circular, but some triangular ones with faint edges on all of them... in circular patterns alternating between circular and somewhat orthogonal grid... in concentric bands (like a pebble ripple in water I guess)...
I did not see the rhythm to be consistent... almost as having a start / stop effect and repeating that pattern.... also the red turned into an orange like color after a minute or 2.
The black ended up shifting between a greenish black and deep blue.
It gave in a headache nearly instantly after starting it... I have tinitus, so the white noise did not do anything... concentrating in the image made the sound fade away and the tinitus came in at a higher than normal volume in my head.
Weird experience to say the least.

By not focusing on the screen, I was able to briefly see what looked like three dimensional movement going inward, like a "wormhole". I do not know if I actually saw it or just made a mental connection to how soap bubbles deform as they multiply.

column10:
For the first 5 or so minutes it was nothing but a quickly flashing red screen. The white noise and screen together gave me an uneasy feeling, but nothing noteworthy, just a "If this was a horror movie this would be the part where someone dies" feeling. Nothing serious, just subtle in the back of my mind, I was fine to continue viewing - I think it was more the white noise static than anything -.
After a while (around 5m) I realized that if I stared at a point, It would seem like everything was flickering from that point. It was around this time that the blue hues started appearing as well. They did not interfere with the red, it was more like I was seeing "in-between" the red flashes, just the screen would for a fraction of a second appear blue between flashes of red. 
Occasionally the focus point would have somewhat different shades of red (generally lighter, as if an outdent or maybe indented from the rest?), and this would continue slightly in short maybe inch long lines sun-raying out from the point. However these lines would pretty much disappear when I blinked. 
At one point after staring for maybe 3 minutes the pace of flickering increased and it got a  yellowish hue, flashing red to yellow to grey-blue, but this effect did not last for more than 2 or 3 seconds before it went back to just red and grey/blue. I was unable to repeat the effect. However, whenever I looked at a point for long enough, it did feel like the rate of flickering increased.

I never had anything other than a red flicker on a Thinkpad in a dark bedroom with scary static though.
column11: 5-7 minutes, For the first five or so minutes nothing happened. After that if I focused on any given point for more than a minute it would start to seem to flicker "from" that point (eminating outward). Moreover, I saw "lines" of what looked like indendation in the red (different hue) coming from that point. Also whenver I was focusing on the screen I would begin to see hues of blue inbetween the red, and at one point it appeared yellow.
column12: If I focused on a point for more than a minute I would get it to flicker from there. I had maybe 3 times total where the "lines" appeared. The blue hues were constant after around the 5 minute mark -- In the flashes where red was not visible the screen would be a dark grey blue color. The yellow was only once after maybe 3 minutes of constant focus.
column13: No images, only the screen appearing to be blue.
column14: As long as I focused on the screen I could keep the blue hues constant. The yellow hue vanished when I blinked. The lines would remain for a few seconds before essentially being the same as the rest.
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy, Slight to Moderate sense of dread.
column16: When I would stare at a point on screen for a while my focus would sort of fade, like what usually happens when you try to focus on the same thing for a while - your mind wants to wander - Those moments of losing focus were somewhat relaxing, but I remained mostly alert. The whole experience made me feel vaguely uneasy, like a sense of dread in the back of my mind, although it was not severe.

column10: Honestly, I watched it two times. The first time was with my eyes open. Then I get to see like an unclear black X in the middle of the screen. Then after a short while I experienced light coming in from the above that got brighter and brighter. It was not actual light, but more of a brightiss white, but not clear white. Then I got other colors that I can't really remember at this point and then I stopped after maybe 3 minutes. When I opened my eyes after that the screen was more of orange color and seemed more solid than red/black flicker.

column10: I could not see anything but could still tell what was supposed to be there. It was from the view point of the edge of a pond, there was a clear sky with stars, a few clouds, and waning crescent moon. On the far edge and wrapping around the shore was a treeline that consisted of birch like trees (tall and thinner wih plenty of canopy, but were not birches) and some juniper trees, it was accompanied with average pond foliage like cattails and reeds and such. There were dragonflys, frogs, flies, birds, and fish, oh and a turtle that had climbd outta the moss and onto a dead tree that was partially submerged. Its almost like i could touch it before I'd be able to see it.

column10: I saw mainly hexagonal shapes next to each other as if you placed them together edge to edge. They usually made up a larger hexagonal shape that was about 20% of the field and around it were other hexagonal shapes like edge to edge with it. Almost like when you're looking at those zoom in fractals and it's just a repeating video as it zooms in, if that makes sense. It actually very much reminded me of what things look like when I'm on acid. I see similar hexagonal shapes etched into whatever I'm looking at. At one point I saw what almost looked like a geometric flower too. And I could see a very light green sometimes but only in the middle of the image. Almost like that thing where you stare at a red for a while and then look at the wall, that kind of green.

column10: I saw quickly shifting ripples, fireworks, fractals, and other complex geometric designs, which were black on a red backdrop.  I began to also see streaks of white. column10: I saw transparent hexagon-like pixels rotating in a fractal like pattern.  The red remained constant, but the black became a dark green, and then alternated to different color harmonies (primary, secondary, tertiary, etc.) in each frame. The top corners of each of these colored frames were darker, and the bottom corners lighter. The hexagon pixels became more of lines moving up and down, then side to side.  The left and right edges of the frame then became a pulsating light yellow.
column15: Lost a sense of space, went from a passive to an active state of observation/consciousness
column16: I felt fully alert, but much more actively focused and absorbed in the space/movement of the screen. Interestingly, when describing this experience and recalling it in memory, I have abstract mental imagery such as a field of flowers, a construction site, and a level of a video-game, as well as textures, smells, flavors, and sounds associated with the memory of the experience, but separate from what I observed in the actual experience itself.

column10: I saw what looked like a chess board shape, then a grid of black lines (similar to the optical illusion where you look at a grid with thick black lines and see circles appear at where the lines intersect), then concentric circles that started from a black spot in the center, then spiderwebs. While I experienced those visuals in that order initially, they did appear in random order afterwards. After about 5 minutes, most all visuals relatively disappeared and I was unable to see anything except the screen changing colors (with small hints of the chess board shape). The shapes all appeared black visually.

column10: i was surprised to learn the flicker went from red to black.  I saw more of a blue color than red that it would flash to, and as some rivers would form in the center of the screen they would have orange and yellow.  then the river would move diagonally and then disappear.  I would occasionally see small boxes, ~15, flash and go away, and the sides of my computer screen would have vertical black columns.  I felt a little strange while doing this, and was actually slightly uncomfortable, telling myself i have never had a seizure, this is okay.  I did stop it earl and then go back and redo it before writing this after learning that there weer just 2 colors, red and black flashing.  The second time the patter was more like a river or a thick rainbow of lightning, but the first time it was more of an oval shape, with fractal edges that I tried to go through but would disappear when i would try.  It would then come back.  It seemed to happen in a pattern, where i could almost expect the image to form after the speed of the flicker would change, like filming a spinning wheel.

column10:
In order of typical experience after imagery was 'reset' by a blink:

Colors other than red/black (green, blue, yellow). These would go away and there would be a general feeling of motion, as if the screen itself were drifting but not actually seeing motion. Apparent motion was generally in a diagonal direction. 3-4 lines would form (spaced respectively ~120 or 90 degrees apart) radiating out from where I was looking, which would rotate around clockwise or counterclockwise (sometimes switching direction). Alternating dark/light bands moving in from the edges or out from the center. The lines collapsed into a point or small circle which would drift around the screen, and the dark/light bands would flow from that point giving a sensation like going through a tunnel (very similar to stereotypical "traveling through a wormhole" imagery in any number of popular sci-fi TV shows or movies). After a few seconds of this I usually would have to blink and the images would be gone.
column14: Persisting several seconds, Until I would blink
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy, As if in a dreamlike state
column16:
Very relaxed and calm, but still aware of my surroundings. A strange sensation that I guess in a word could best be described as feeling "disconnected" that persists for some time afterwards - for example I am obviously still in full control of my body and can type normally into this box and although I'm composing what I'm writing as normal it feels almost like my hands are doing their own thing, typing on their own.

Felt virtually identical to how it has felt in the past when I've viewed an autostereogram (specifically the music video for "Black Is Good" by Young Rival on Youtube) or when I once participated in a stage performer's hypnosis routine.

column10: It almost immediately turned into a flicker of many times the speed as the original rate. Then brighter and darker spots began to take form, and move in spiral patterns. There was a hint of deeper patterns, but it also had the TV static feel. After some time, I started to perceive blues, and the pattern rotation went away. A couple times, I saw shapes that seemed distinct and real, such as a dark forest. The other times were vague and felt impossible to describe. I looked away a couple times, which seemed to trigger a reset on the sensation, but it was always very fast to immerse again. Also, the patterns seemed to match up with the audio in a way that was hard to describe... like there was a baseline that matched up with certain expansions of the light portions of the flickering.

column10: It started as nothing, but I was very anxious since I have what I call "full force aphantasia" which means I have absolutely no sense of smell, tough, taste, sight, or hearing in my head, so I was worried that I may have hallucinations or hear things that could scare me, but as time went on nothing really changed. By what felt about the 1/2 way point I began to relax, and I began to see small distortions in the screen. First it was the area around the edge of the screen turning more pale, and occasionally white, then the lights started flickering in a slower rhythm, but I refocused my eyes and it went back to normal. At what I assume was about the 7 minute point I began to see distortions that looked like horizontal diamonds, or possibly eyes, but there were many of them, in no apparent order. They were by no means vivid, but it seemed like it was parts of my eyes registering the change in colour faster than others, rather than a hallucination. After about 30 seconds my vision went back to normal. I heard no huge change in the audio, but by the 6 minute mark the audio sounded like rain, possibly in a rain forest. And once the test was finished my vision was a bit wavy around the edges, and I had tinnitus in both ears for about 7 minutes afterwards.
column12: No images, but the changes I experienced happened about once per change, all in the span of about 4-5 minutes.
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy, Lost a sense of time
column16: I became relaxed about halfway, as I had been stressed and worried about how the test may affect me. I also lost a sense of time, the first 3 minutes felt very long, but the 4-8 minute marks went by very quickly, as I thought I might have started to experience some of the effects, and then the last 2 minutes felt dragged on. These are approximate times, as I was not keeping track, I had an alarm off to the side that was set for 10 minutes.

column10: Just the usual visual "snow" (like the "snow" on a non-broadcasting TV station) with flickering red and black. I did seem to see a small optical illusion where it looked like the top inch or so of the browser window was black, gradually grading into red (akin to applying a narrow black gradient on a red background). The grading was vertical, but a little lumpy horizontally (kind of like how glaze on the rim of a cup has a lumpy inconsistent edge). There were also changes in perceived depth of field; it felt less like the flat surface of a computer screen and more like it should be possible to peer into, although I didn't see any objects, just the usual "snow." The visual snow seemed like it occasionally had more short linear segments than is typical (rather than being  composed of simple snow "pixels" as is usually the case for me). However, I wouldn't know if that's what I would expect to happen, if for example, I stared at a blank wall for 10 minutes; I do have "floaters" in my normal vision.
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy
column16: I wasn't sure if it was better to be attentive or to relax attention, so I tried both at different times. Kind of like how one might try to change their perception when viewing one of those 3D posters from the 1990s. When I relaxed my attention was when I perceived a depth of field, and when I started to feel a little more relaxed. I occasionally meditate, and it felt like there was less mental chatter towards the end, as I was relaxing into the experience. It was more settling into the relaxation of attention kind of sensation, rather than anything hypnotic or an altered state of consciousness.

column10:
Mostly geometric shapes, with 'waves' of that shape reminiscent of a moiré, emanating to fill field of vision occupied by Ganzflicker. . For example a full-screen plus, that would switch colors with each flash, and each time it switched colors the old color would get displaced in every direction (so you'd be left with right-angle color bands moving towards each corner). The same thing, but with a diagonal cross on the screen. Radial lines from the center, rotating clocking or counterclockwise. An alternating checkerboard. With more time between blinks: weirder, less regular patterns, with a different color each 'frame'. Occasionally the sense of a 3D object, but not clear imagery of it - like tracking a plane flying by, "turning" towards it flying away.

I also tried watching it in a VR headset with it filling my entire field of view. There were still patterns, but they were much less clear - more like full color changes of all or nearly all of my entire field of view rather than detailed patterns. In VR it was super easy to also see patterns with eyes closed, as it lit up the eyelids better.
column14: Constant, morphing from one image to the next, Images seemed to "reset" upon blinking. Got more intense the longer I could keep my eyes open.
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy, As if in a dreamlike state, Lost a sense of time
column16: Just generally super relaxed, the boxes checked above do justice to describing the feeling. I have also had this exact same feeling induced by extended viewing of optical illusions - one in particular that always invokes this exact state is a particular famous music video by "Young Rival" where it is several minutes of autostereogram set to music, that's only visible when you stare at the screen in a certain way. Also reminds me of a time I participated in a stage hypnotist's show - induced a completely different way, and completely voluntary, but still feels similar.

column10: Mostly just saw a bunch of lines, some curved lines, and a few circles. The most intense thing I saw was instead of red/black flashes, it became static red/black squares. Their appearance reminded me of the old tv static, especially with the white noise playing. The squares in the top left became smaller and the squares everywhere else became bigger, eventually shifting to the sides of the screen and morphed into flashing spikes. The spikes were 'attached' to the edge of the screen pointing in. More spikes appeared in a radial pattern in the center. After that, everything started rotating and stretching as if going down a spiral. After a few seconds, everything became so stretched and distorted that the spikes just merged back into the red/black flashing. This happened around 3/4 minutes in, and nothing else like it happened.

column10: Sometimes it seemed as if there was a swaying motion of the whole visual field, back and forth, from left to right. Other times lines of color would emanate from a ball of light. At one point there was the sensation of the lights rotating and also moving across the screen as they rotated. Towards the end of the ten minutes I saw something that looked like a grid or spiderweb of black lines in the center of the screen.

column10: There was a random non static flickering pattern, similar to coarse Perlin noise, with a darker shade of red color. Then in the middle of my eye focus point I could see a cross spanning roughly for half of the screen, flickering too, but mainly bright red. The cross was sometimes rotating, and sometimes there was a second cross superimposed at 45 degree. The cross at times was just a line with the other branches very dimm. The cross appeared almost at the beginning of the section. Towards the end of the session I think I saw a spiral shape. Overall this imagery was very mild and barely discernable from the red background.

column10:
Various geometric and organic shapes, usually with rotational symmetry. The center of the symmetry was wherever my eyes were focused. Most commonly this was like a crosshair an inch or two thick across the entire screen. It was like two lines of rectangles, vertical and horizontal, and the rectangles were defined by thin dark not-quite-black (maybe dark green) lines. When I put on the shepard tone, almost immediately what I saw changed so there were no more shapes but it seemed like the color change was a right-to-left wipe instead of an instant transition. Eventually the "crosshair" returned, and from that point on it was mostly just the crosshair and occasionally seeing the "real" flashing red and black.

Also, I never actually saw a true black. I'm not sure what color I saw, best I can describe is a very dark green.

column10: Constantly morphing patterns that changed according to which part of the screen that I focused on. There were typical electric blue lines and starburst patterns emerging for a few seconds and the colour range changed the longer that I watched the Ganzflicker (the red began to tend more toward orange and the black became more bluish and then greenish). If I defocused my vision, I easily went into a trance state and mild feeling of floating/travelling. About 3 minutes into watching I tranced out and fell asleep for a few seconds before jolting awake with my eyes open. For the first few minutes there was tendency towards boredom but as I went on the sense of novelty increased and by the end of the ten minutes all sense of time had disappeared and I was really enjoying the experience.

column10: After perhaps 20-30 seconds to "acclimatize" to the display, I saw brief pauses in the flicker every 1-2 seconds, as though a frame of color lasted 2-3 times longer than usual.  These mostly happened with red, not black, and were screen-wide.  Other than that, I saw very basic patterns appearing as contrast changes, extremely similar to migraine with visual aura (which I suffer from.) I found these neither fascinating (old news for me) nor unpleasant (because they were not paired with nausea, hemiplegia, or brain fog.)  I did not see complex shapes or images.  I have a vivid imagination, but also have much difficulty remembering people's faces.  When seeing people I do know I rarely remember their names, and often it takes me awhile and context clues to identify them.  This includes family members, close friends and coworkers.  I rarely associate names to faces, though I can tell you confidently whether I know a name.  I can only recall very generic facial characteristics such as "male, gray hair, smiles alot."  I do have excellent mental spatial map, to the point that I can draw very detailed maps and details of buildings, including cardinal orientation.  For some reason, now that I think on it, these rarely include confidence in color information (e.g., floor color, paint and trim is uncertain) but texture and position details are very vivid.
column14: Constant, morphing from one image to the next
column15: Lost a sense of time, Alert but hyper-focused on the Ganzflicker, tuning out other external stimuli.
column16: I immediately noticed my eyes widen and blinking cease.  I am able to cease blinking for several minutes at a time at will (with 30 seconds or so of focus), but in this case I did not intend to go into this state.  It was interesting being almost instantly in that mode, and took focus to break it -- I had to choose to blink rather than choose to not blink.  I also felt like my perception of time was skewing.  I have, ever since I was a young child, had periods where my the flow of time changes to glacial in relation to my mental state.  This includes my movement and bodily responses, with the effect that I'm trapped in my own body.  It is deeply unpleasant.  My experience with the change of sense of time while viewing the Ganzflicker was not the same as these personal episodes (much like how the visual effects I experienced were similar to my migraine auras but lacked the other negative sensations.)  However, because of the similarity I chose to end the visualization.  Within a few seconds of stopping the Ganzflicker, I was fully alert in the here and now.

column10: Any shape or "image" I saw was seemingly anchored to where I was directly looking. If I shifted my gaze to the left or right side of the screen, that point would become the center of any visual change. The only other color I saw was blue and, in fact, the blue seemed to replace the black. If I kept my eyes straight ahead, the image would be a brief flash, but if I allowed myself to "follow" the movement, it would last for a few seconds. The experience was more sleep-inducing than brain-stimulating. Perhaps it is because I woke up 20 minutes prior, but I had nearly 8 hours of sleep, which is normal for me and I woke up on my own without an alarm. Most of the shapes I saw were geometric. One specific shape extended out diagonally from the center in a starburst pattern, but it wasn't nearly as vivid as the word would suggest. There was one 3D image that was vaguely perceived. It was not any real object, but rather something similar to a hand-held mining drill like one would find in a video game. (Terraria or Roblox) The colors did not change and the object seemed to rotate as if in a display case for about 3-5 seconds. Then, it was gone and never returned. It did not seem like a life-like image. When the 10 minutes was complete, I had lost track of time and was surprised by how quickly it was over.

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), pyramid and depth
column10:
At first I saw short lines in all different directions around mostly the peripheral of the monitor. I got interrpted and had to start over after 5 minutes, then I saw dots everywhere. 
Then I saw something like a shape of an island on a lake...mind you i didnt see an island or a lake. it wasnt realistically colored or anything Just felt like i was standing on the edge of a lake looking at something in the middle of it. It just felt far away like if i got closer it would get bigger. 

it went away but then came back a few minutes later. Less like an island and more like shaped like a pyramid. That went away too. 

I also felt like the screen was getting closer and closer to me. I didn't want it to get too close to me, but only because outside of the screen, in my peripheral vision, everything felt super dark in my bedroom with the lights out (its still daytime outside, but i have blackout curtains). It felt like if i got too involved in the screen, if i let it get too close to me, then the darkness in the room would move. Essentially it felt like maybe there was something there in my room in the dark but really it was my dresser. but seeing it out of the corner of my eye while watching the screen was not pleasant .so when the screen got too close to me, I would look at the bottom of the screen so that my vision would re adjust and the screen would 'go back' to being the regular distance away from my eyes again. it would begin to pulse toward me closer, right away again, and i found  i wanted to let it keep doing that, but i stopped it because of the darkness of the corner of my room.

column10: Dark lines, spider web patterns, simple geometric shapes. At times the lines/shapes were alternatively indigo or black. The shapes tended to be somewhat indistinct and fuzzy rather than discrete. Sometimes the red background and sometimes the black/indigo colours would achieve dominance in my focus depending on my mental state or level of trance I was in at the time. Towards the end of the 10 minutes that I watched, the edge of the screen had a kind of greenish border all the way around. For a few minutes after I finished watching, the flicker, I could see a distinct alternating/pulsing black and white pattern in my visual field with my eyes closed.
column15: As if in a dreamlike state
column16: My states of consciousness varied considerably throughout the experience all the way from hyper-alert and mentally analytical through to trance like dreamy states where patterns and imagery became far more easy to generate or passively experience. When hyper-alert, analytical or deliberate, images or random sounds were far less likely to manifest at all or were rather faint.

column10:
I have Aphantasia and as far as I can tell, this was the closest I’ve come to ‘visualising’. It was like watching a trippy video of colours and sounds.

Audibly: I heard a sort of monophonic ringtone sound that was increasing notes...chromatically if I’m not mistaken...no actual tune to it. At one point it did seem to be random notes, not in any order but not what I would describe as tuneful. 

Visually: I saw, initially, lines jutting out from the centre of my vision forming a star, a cross, an X and then I was able to sort of ride the lines with my perspective...like falling through a tunnel or riding a rollercoaster. I then saw large balls floating around on the outside of my vision and I was eventually able to look at them and follow their random paths. I then saw streaks of rainbow or spectrum travel fairly steadily across my vision. 

I was able to relax my vision from time to time to try and see more but the random assortment of simple and semi complex shapes would have me unknowingly sort of ‘focus’...as in near vision or far vision...if that makes sense. At one point I saw red and black checkerboard which would increase in size or decrease depending on how close/far I focused my vision.

I really want to “cure” my Aphantasia...

I tried viewing the flicker on an Oculus Go VR headset, but the flicker was temperamental and not steady on it’s built in browser. I ended up using an iPad Pro 12 inch with headphones on and held it as close to my face as I could.

I will be repeating this as well as the Ganzfeld videos I’ve seen that are constant red with white noise.

Hope this helps. Anything else you want to know or would like me to try feel free to get in touch:

It was usually a right to left movement, but it really wasn't because I saw objects moving. I would just occasionally feel like the screen was moving, almost like the computer screen was a car window the and flicker was moving along outside as landscape.

column16: I became very sleepy. I was having trouble keeping my eyes open. I also became uncomfortable. My eyes hurt, and I would find difficulty focusing them on anything, leading to a general unfocused stare at the screen.

column16:
I felt rather dissociated. I wasn't really aware of the space around me or between myself and the screen. I felt relaxed and meditative, like I was in a trance. My sense of time seemed to be changing as well, as it seemed to be flickering at a changing speed.

This was all very fascinating considering that I experience virtually zero imagery under any other circumstance!

column8: Somewhat unpleasant, but didn't mind going on
column9: My eyes adjusted to the colors and movements and what finally came into focus was the room behind me.   Apparently the computer acted as a mirror and I was able to see myself,  the windows, pictures on the wall etc.
column10: I saw a reflection of myself and what was behind me in the room.   Once my eyes were able to see beyond the movements of the colors, they focused and I was able to see myself.   It was all muted.   Oddly, it gradually came into focus during the first 5 minutes or so and then became much sharper until the film was over.    I at first thought I was seeing something in my imagination, but it was a reflection.    I'm pretty sure I have aphantasia and the only time I have visualized was on LSD and when dreaming.

The shapes are mostly in the center but sometimes they were slightly off, like the triangle.

I had to look away several times because it was uncomfortable.

column10:
In the beginning the flash was rather regular then all of a sudden it started changing direction strobing for a few seconds than rolling like an old TV screen then rolling right to left. when it strobed I could see a faint circle in the middle and blue, green and black dots lines and bursts of light, all also faint but visible.
Several times the screen went totally still and constant red. I would say it lasted about two seconds max. 
I noticed in the beginning my mind, my voice in my head was all over the place and it calmed down and felt very peaceful then. That is what I noticed most of all, a calm feeling while viewing. My minds voice stopped thinking and was able to listen.

You may want to know that I have hearing loss (adult) and a Cochlear Implant. I also have Dry AMD in early stages. 
When doing this the room was dark and the hearing device removed so only the sound of my very loud tinnitus was audible.

column10:
It was like a story was showen to me in images. Through the white noise I either heard chirping bird or dark wordless vocals depending on what turn the story takes I assume. I didn’t understand the story fully but some parts were obvious. I’ve seen multiple humans and could differentiate their various actions and movements even though everything was smugy and happening quickly, very similar to visions on psychedelics. 

One time a character moved diagonally into my direction and came uncomfortable close. It literally felt/looked like someone came very close to me and I even moved back out of reflex. 

Through my eyes I saw constantly evolving patterns on the screen that always sort of formed a X through symmetry. They were mostly a bright blue with a greenish-yellow shadow around them.

column16:
I felt very unsafe from blocking off two important senses and at times it felt quite like I am becoming a part of the patterns or one of the patterns itself. 
Becoming a point of focus in the story once made me uncomfortable. 
Whenever something persisted for a long time or something similar I can’t put in words I felt quite anxious, I assume that’s because that makes those hallucinations feel quite feel and sentient, I’ve got that impression a few times which is something very new and unexpected to me.

column10: It's difficult to describe but I'll give it a shot. You know how if you glance at the sun, the image is kind of burned into your eyes and has that weird, noisy-color visual? after a while of staring at the flashing it started to have a similar noisy-color look to it, centering in the middle of the image and spinning. the visual itself didn't have a concise shape, like it wasn't a sphere or anything, but it moved in a funneling manner, like if you did one of those experiments where you create a 'tornado' in water by creating a vortex. if you looked at such a vortex from above, that is pretty much what the visual looked like.

column10: Most flickers were obvious flickers, but at times blended into a continuum; screen was oranigish most of the time, no other colours. The two brief moments of seeming spiral galaxies rotating may derive from my experience with astronomy visualisations. I was disappointed at such a bland return from my imagination, as I enjoy daily visual views of our garden and animals as vividlly coloured and greatly detailed.  I was hoping for hallucinatory images of magnificent beauty, but no such events happened. I recall from my last experiences after smoking marijuana and one experience with mescaline nearly 50 years ago as vividly as when they occurred, and yet nothing like those vibrant arabesques and Chartres-like vivid colourations occurred in any way. I kept my eyes centred and close to the screen so as not to be distracted, then waited ... and waited ... and waited. Nothing of note occurred, neither irritating nor pleasurable. Odd, because I see real-world colours very vividly and with great pleasure. As a hobbyist astronomer I see unimaginable beauty in the abstract shapes and unearthly hues of star clouds and nebulae in images from the far-IR, microwave and MM bands, and astrophysical simulations such as the Illustris simulations of the Cosmic Web, Planck Telescope magnetic field imagery, and Chromoscope visualisation interfaces. Nothing of the sort occurred while watching Ganzflicker. I thank you for your throughtfulness in putting this experiment together, but the real world does much more for me.
column11: I saw seeming colour shifts and two brief episodes of seeming spinning galaxies
column12: 1 or 2 times in the whole experience
column15: No change, fully alert in the here and now
column16: I felt no changes whasoever. Odd, because I practice a form of meditation whose goal is to merge all discrete external sounds into a continuum. It is a goal seldom achieved, but when it does it is a unity-state in which all thing are one thing and one thing is all things. For me, the veil between the One and the All is gossamer which I freely transit at will using a form of divine love, or karuna as Theravada Buddhism call it, as the energy carrier. Thank you again for your experience, but we are clearly on very different energy levels.

column10: Most of the color that I saw was this red-orange stuff. Immediately after starting to stare at the screen, some black diffused big circles, like shadows not completely black but gray started to fill the screen. Sometimes I could see "rays" of light just crossing the screen and sometimes they move, they were a little bit inclined to the right.  like this symbol: / . Not very intense, they were reddish. At some point, I perceived the red was bright on one side, like the colors of intense sunset. I could see rarely and for a very short time, like less than 5 seconds, some "mesh" or "spider web",  but very small, like inside a 2 cm diameter circle without defined boundaries. Most of the time I perceived everything blurred. The most interesting thing that happened was when the music stopped. When the white noise stopped I felt the screen getting closer to me, like a little bit the way you feel the screen in a 3D movie at the theatre. I thought something was going to happen like I was going to see something, but then I perceived other noises in the room, like the air conditioner, that's how I realized the music was over and that I wasn't having an auditory hallucination where I could no longer listen to the white noise.

column9: Distortions (e.g., screen warping or rotating), Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes)
column10: most of the time there was a vague impression of two perpendicular lines that were not centered, horizontal/vertical, or perfectly straight that described a "focal point' near the center. That focal point would move in shallow arcs back and forth across the screen or in circles and ovals giving a 3D impression (the circular movement was not parallel to the screen) and usually the movement would increase in speed until I blinked or changed my attention which started the perpendicular lines again. There were also vague impressions of shapes filling the quadrants of the screen described by the perpendicular lines, generally roughly circular and tiled and occasionally varying sizes. None of the lines or shapes were strong like a pencil drawing on paper would be, but very vague and shadowy. The only color change was a slight pinking of the edges of the screen. Overlying the screen and the few details outside the screen I could see in my peripheral vision (it was dusk and very dim but not full dark in my room) was a noise or static pattern in white, like dots.

column10: mostly just different contrasting reds. It was like someone was TRYING to show me something, but it never could form, as you are making a graphic for an add with a solid red background, and there is *something* overlayed, but the transparency level was so high, It was just a smidge bit darker red. at first it was mostly a large crooked X, then later towards the bottom almost like a mechanical gear of a clock? occasionally, it would be cheveron print lighter red that I could barely see, but they were gone seconds later
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy
column16: I never could make i past the 7 minute mark. as the video progressed, it made my vision start to blur, my eyes lose focus and almost cross, and I became almost in a trance. My eyes kept drooping down, and finally closing with my head drooped down. But, right before my eyes fully closed, and I was out of focus but looking through the eyelashes right before they shut, THEN I could see the most detail. It was very brief and mostly at the bottom of the screen, but my eyes would shut so I lost it. Then in my eyelids (if that makes sense, it was a large black rectangle with bursts behind it. I tried it twice and was so disappointed!!! I wanted it to work SO BAD. OOH! on a previous page about what i saw, I did have a little light coming from the next room beside me. In front of me, I can see into the dark living room. Okay, both times I watched the video, towards the top right corner OUTSIDE of my laptop over in the distance, I saw movement that I know wasn't really there, and as soon as my eyes left the screen, it was gone. That happened a couple of times each time.

column10: Mostly simple straight lines, usually white, occasionally black. They were thin, no more than a centimeter wide. Sometimes they rotated. Individual lines usually presisted for a couple of seconds before fading. Sometimes only single lines appeared, occasionally multiple at the same time, sometimes crossing each other. The most was three or four distinct lines, crossing over each other, in a vaguely A-like shape. Occasionally there were spherical regions of white or black. None of the above imagery felt particularly vivid or alive, they just were there.

column10: Rainbow coloured lines (roughly 2cm wide and spanning the full length of the screen).  They were made up of purple, red, green, orange, white, and maybe other colours as you might have from a spectrum.   The lines were basically all of equal width like you would have in a rainbow but the white wasn't a line but more so the occasional dot.  The lines sometimes changes angles and the number of lines changes.  Sometimes they intersected.  They flickered on and off with the red screen, which made me more wondering if that was a somewhat expected experience based on the RGB colours of the monitor, the computer refresh rate, the red flickering speed, and the cones in my eyes.  They stopped as soon as I stopped looking at the flickering red/black screen.

column16: Could easily close my eyes and go to sleep.  I wanted it to end (except that I wanted to keep going out of curiosity); something felt disturbing or scary or violent.  When the shapes moved forcefully up and down, I imagined a kind of pounding or hitting.  When the shapes were spinning, I felt a kind of getting lost inside a washing machine...  And when the shapes kind of pulled me in, there was a pleasant sense of moving through a forest, although I didn't see a forest vividly, per se.

column10:
The overall visual experience seemed to be very geometric or abstract landscapes built from sonographs. There appeared to be movement and flow, sometimes stopping to intensify. The white noise gave it more depth.  I should like to try it in a still and quiet environment.  When the white noise ended I found it fascinating to hear the echoes slowly fade for a few seconds.

White balls of light form from shafts at the vertices - like wells and peaks on a gravitational surface.

column10:
The red flash seemed to transition from flashing to rolling. At one point it looked like i was in a starship warp where the lights were flashing by me really fast but that went away. 

Mostly i saw lines like the seams of a soccer ball and what appeared to be like running water lines in a stream. The star like light flashes would come and go but that was not really showing me a lot of images. I thought once I saw something like the surface of the moon and then it turned to patters of running water and then back to shapes like the soccer ball.

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black, Rapidly changing hidden line cartoon shapes hinting at people, green coral like structure for very short time, squiggles around the edges of the screen like a border
column10: The screen pattern changed constantly, nothing regular it was almost was like tiny runs of patterns but as soon as it felt like it was repeating it changed. Grey shapes mainly, yellow/orange edge to the screen often and sometimes a black or red edge. I saw a starburst/ firework style shape occasionally and a couple of little sparks like a sparkler. The frame of the screen has faded squiggles around it, like thin wiggly lines in the colour of a fading afterglow of a sparkler but that doesn’t fully disappear, but only in my peripheral vision. If I looked directly at them they disappeared. In the early minutes I also felt like I was seeing hidden line drawings occasionally behind the patterns, like a grown up drawing in a childish stick figure style, but you could never focus on it and they flickered past too quickly to register what they were meant to be. Once I felt like half the screen moved back and green coral like shape appeared on a lighter background but it disappeared in a second or less and never reappeared. Mainly my experience was like looking at a strobe light/theatre lights creating non repeating pattern style chaos.

column8: No feeling about it one way or the other
column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes)
column10: Throughout the whole thing and in between other flashes it would be as if I was traveling very fast or falling. Like when Doctor Strange was pushed through multiple dimensions but not as vivid, just me traveling between two walls or galaxies (but again, it wasn't detailed at all). Another example is it looked like I was falling town a tunnel in Minecraft. Like I was in one of those games (within Minecraft) where people drop down a colorful tunnel (but it wasn't as colorful, just had a very light tone to it. Not dark at all) and try to land in a specific spot. But I never landed, the image ended before I ever could. Most of the time I would see lines going to a vanishing point and I was falling fast. Sometimes the lines would originate in the bottom left corner of the screen for some reason. There were about 2-3 instances where I was zooming out of something. In one I started super zoomed into something and quickly zoomed out and saw Earth (not very detailed, just a planet with some random land that my mind probably wanted to see so I saw it). Another one seemed like I saw the silhouette of a dead body and was zooming out of that. It didn't lead anywhere, it looked like the body was just getting farther away/smaller. About after the 3-4 minute mark the screen appeared to be getting bigger, like a camera was getting closer to the screen and was about to engulf it and the next scene was in the computer screen but it wasn't actually in a computer, they just zoomed in and made a transition. Nothing lasted more than 5 seconds, and in between I just saw symmetrical shapes and psychedelic images like the scene transitions in That 70s Show just without the people.
column15: No change, fully alert in the here and now
column16: I was fully alert the entire time, but it felt like I could be engulfed in the flicker and wouldn't mind or could lose time. But I didn't feel like I was about to, I was in full control of my sense of time and space the entire time.
column17: In the center, Sometimes the lines would originate from the bottom left corner

column9: Colors other than red and black, single frame flashes of scratches at the start, single frame flashes of balls after several minutes,  rotations of the field that persisted for several seconds after several minutes
column10: To start I saw what looked like scratches on the screen in the sense that they did not alter the colour and were a little like "floaters". After several minutes it was hard to identify what colour I was perceiving, but a strong colour did not present, rather an inability to determine the colour. At times I would perceive a surface rotating around the center point at a few rpm, namely a little faster than a second hand would travel on a clock. For periods of 10s of seconds and after about 4 minutes, I would see some structure in the initial flash such as balls or bubbles but without any persistence so that it was strobing. I never saw any larger structure, or any imagery that persisted except for the sensation of rotation

column10: To start, a predominantly red screen with undefined blue blobs on it followed by a blurry, checkered corridor in the centre half of the screen, coloured blue and red, disappearing into infinity. Then a predominantly red screen with undefined blue blobs on it, then the same with randomly placed patches of white noise that grouped and disappeared. Later on a reasonably defined checkered tube, disappearing into infinity. I also noticed that, at the start, my eyes kept flicking down and to the left even though I tried to hold them in the centre of the screen.

column10:
With the white noise mostly the pulsating red light and a bit of distorsion.

With other musics: At first only random lines. Sometimes like moving watercolors with reds and blues, lots of purples and pinks, yellows in the bottom. Once a pink tunnel. Or like traveling through space at great speed, for and backwards. Only a couple of times saw figures in space, like spacecraft moving, nebulaes and a balcony over the universe. But most of the time the annoyying pulsating light.

NOTE: I have a hyperactive mind and an internal TV going at very fast pace all the time, images morphing into other images. I am on ADHD meds, gradually the imaginery slowed and became more simplistic all the way to seeing black. I also have trouble imagining visually on demand, but have vivid dreams and in a way I know in my head what things look like. 

I actually turned around and closed my eyes to see if I could have images again and had some very slow moving, like a purple aquatic plant floating over an ugly curtain-like fabric.

Before ADHD diagnosis I found out psychedelics actually slow down my inner eye.

column10: After a few minutes, I saw a semi-geometric pattern filling most of the screen. A lattice of triangles or maybe pentagrams. This lasted for a few minutes. After about five minutes, a view of a city gradually emerged, but it was like viewing through thin clouds. The view was from the air - like what you might see from an airplane window after takeoff or before landing. The cityscape view did not change or move. That image only lasted about 2 minutes. After that, the experience reminded me of looking at a cloudy sky with a lot of persistent lightning flashes.

column10: After watching for a few minutes, my eyes would start to blur and the screen would look distorted and three dimensional, like the whole screen was moving closer to me. When I blinked the sensation would go away, and then it would take a few more minutes before it happened again. The image that I was seeing on the screen (flashing red) didn't seem to change, but it seemed to move.

column10: amorphous blobs of greenish color, a bit elongated, radom shaped. At one point they were bluish. I would concentrate on the center of the screen mostly, sometimes I did not notice them but would evoke awareness of them by gently “remembering” that they were there. So, not particularly intense, or “demanding” attention. At one point I saw clear, short horizontal lines across the screen, lasting for a minute or so. There were just three or four of them. I questioned if this was due to my eyelids being somewhat down as I was delaying my eyes looking at the flicker. These did not last the whole time, and they did not vanish when I opened my eyes fully.

column10:
For the first 2 minutes, nothing much. Just what the brain would see when exposed to rapidly flashing colors. They kinda blend together and it warps a bit.
After 2 minutes, though, it felt like one of those scenes in movies where a character gets high and we're shown some psychedelic scene with wacky visuals and stuff, but it was only made up of a line with a simple symmetrical pattern: Dark colored in the center, Light colored on the sides and everything else was alternating yellow and orange. These lines would cut the screen in half like spiderwebs, and they would always be moving in one direction. They would also sometimes form tubes that I would see myself going through up and down and all around. This was barely visible, and I think 50% of it was my brain interpreting what was vaguely seen and not what I actually saw, but I don't know.

column10: For the first couple of minutes, I was able to see shapes and patterns emerge. Spires branching out in all directions, spinning discs in my peripheral. After a while, though, they stopped and I was left with sporadic flashes of colours that I find difficulty in describing. In the last 3 or so minutes, I can't really explain what I saw, but I felt incredibly anxious.

column10: From the start I would frequently see something in the shape of a commercial wind-mill's blades (i.e. 3 white lines coming from a central point and 120-degrees apart). These did not rotate. Rather they were in a straight row and column configuration that faded in and out. There were 12 (?) in a column, more in a row. The periphery was never really in focus, though that may have been due to my looking at the middle of the screen only. They were sort of whitish, though never became very substantial. About 5 minutes in (I have a poor sense of time passage as well as almost no mind's eye/ear), I'd occasionally see a a faint ellipse that was a bit lighter than the red. Usually it was rounded but sometimes it started to develop corners so that it was more rectangular. This didn't persist for very long, and after that I really didn't see anything else other than the flicker.
column15: No change, fully alert in the here and now, As if in a dreamlike state, Lost a sense of time, I am on medication that has caused my (always poor) time sense to be even worse, and I cannot gauge time very well. So, the experience didn't change my usual state... which is to lose track of time passage.

column10: I saw flickering red and black for the entire 10 minutes. The screen felt mostly red with black flickering on the screen constantly as vague shapes, so it felt like a bunch of squares as opposed to the entire screen becoming black, but nothing distinct, no imagery. If I stared without blinking sometimes the flickering would seem to speed up. By staring for a while, I managed to have the screen feel like it was growing toward me a little bit, but the feeling didn't last and wasn't a strong feeling. I believe I have a very week mind's eye (not sure it's full blown aphantasia--I have been trying to test this recently), so I came at this with an open mind knowing I may only see flickering or I may see hallucinations, or anywhere in between, just open to whatever might happen. I felt disappointed I wasn't seeing anything, but it's also what I would have expected if there is a correlation between the mind's eye and seeing imagery in the Ganzflicker. I did notice, interestingly, that I had very mild (barely noticeable) physical effects that are the same as a marijuana high, which makes my sinuses feel like they are stuffed with cotton. I felt that extremely mildly a few minutes into watching the Ganzflicker and then it dissipated by the time 10 minutes was up.
column15: No change, fully alert in the here and now
column16: I just felt curious about whether or not I would see anything. At a certain point I wondered if the 10 minute white noise clip was actually only 10 minutes long (I was using the white noise clip as my timer), and I almost looked at my phone, but resisted and decided to wait. I knew 10 minutes can feel like a long time if you are just sitting not doing much, and then by the end I was surprised 10 minutes had already passed. So I guess I began to feel mildly impatient about 7 minutes in is my guess, once I had accepted I wouldn't be seeing anything in the Ganzflicker.

column10:
I saw lines oriented in all different directions. I think they were all the same length - ~4-5 cm. The lines were 2-dimensional; flat on the screen. If I allowed my vision to, what I call, "relax" (I think it's like crossing my eyes - I know its how I can the 3D figure hidden in the repeated pattern images that were popular in the late 80s/early 90s), I wouldn't see the lines anymore and the screen would feel like it had depth - inward in the center. Also, the center would stay mostly black, and the periphery of the screen stayed red, although a bright, light red.
For the first half of the experience I had a feeling like I was watching a horror movie. That eventually gave way to a feeling of chaos. None of these feelings were unpleasant to me.

I saw no black, instead it seemed to be flashing between blue and red.
The color transitions seemed to change occationally, as if instead of an instantaneous transition, they were focused on a single point
Sometimes i'd see strange-looking tubes and spirals. Tears in the screen also seemed common
After staring for a few seconds, pieces of faces started appearing, some seemed like real people (none i recognized) but some were of fictional characters, like Homer Simpson and Mario.

column10: Images of things only appeared briefly and seemingly at random except for one. The white noise sounded like water running in a fast river, and I saw abstract ocean waves (abstract because they were red & black) moving across the bottom of the screen for much of the time. Above the waves, objects (an old wooden chair, a doll, the yellow line on a highway--saw that a lot) came towards me or receded. The direction that everything but the waves moved (towards me or away) changed repeatedly and all at once. Things moving towards me didn't scare me; I never lost the knowledge that I was seated quietly at my desk.

At the start i thought i felt a bit motion sick because i got a little lurch in my stomach when it started. but then i got sleepy and wanted to close my eyes, and then when i blinked my eyes i remember it was whiter and brighter than i expected and i remember blinking slowly a lot to see that, without thinking it was unusual to blinking so slowly. i wasn't really relaxed though, i was thinking 'has it been ten minutes yet? maybe i should check the timer'. i knew where i was and was aware of the space around me

column10:
the first to emerge were a few - say three or four black fuzzy edged dots, perceieved diameter of 5mm or so. They moved around a little. Then were gone very soon.
a 'sun', or round area of brighter than the rest the percieved size of a tennis ball which followed the 'focus' area of the eye
a 'galaxy', the sun grew out horixontally like the mikly way - or fried egg - but with quiet distinct lines rather than ovals. 
zig zagging - there appeared to be zig zagged lines like vertical scan lines which were zigging left and right as they moved from top to bottom, by about 2cm perceived
variation / cycles of averaged brightness and 'less flicker' cycling at about a 1 minute interval - a feeling of 'catching up' with the flickering, or 'coming into phase' with it

column9: Distortions (e.g., screen warping or rotating), Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Tunnels
column10: The flashing resolved into swirling geometric shapes, one for each eye that then combined to form a tunnel that I was propelled down at great speed. It was difficult to keep my focus on the centre of the tunnel and as my vision was drawn outward I felt like I was tumbling aimlessly and had to concentrate to regain control. This started the rise of murmurs emerging from the white noise, like distant voices on the wind, and a large and powerful thrumming. The strangest thing was that I have a near constant tone in my right ear from tinnitus, and after about 5-6 minutes I felt that the pattern was interrupting the tone.

column10: The flicker appeared to have a counter-clockwise spiral rotation which was likely simply my own eye movement. This started after a few minutes (4 approx). Early on (the first 1-2 minutes) I saw very faint geometric outlines rather like a kaleidoscope or fractal pattern but these did not persist and stopped after a minute or so.

column10:
The most common type of imagery that I saw were similar to the horizontal or vertical swipe effect that we can see on old television. For example, if I saw horizontal lines there were multiple of them and they seemed to go from the top of the screen to the bottom of the screen. Sometimes both horizontal and vertical lines would be seen at the same time making some kind of grid. The lines were always black. The effect is similar to this: https://youtu.be/3BJU2drrtCM?t=77, but more pronounced like the 1600fps clip in that video. So I could make out the individual lines and they were at an angle.

It happened that sometimes it seemed like I was seeing a pattern like if you were looking at the front of a lit flashlight like this one: https://www.dreamstime.com/stock-photography-led-flash-light-image9174022. The best way to describe it would be red circles in place of where the flashlight LEDs would be and and the black around it is similar to the moving at light-speed effect.

The third pattern I could sometimes see would be similar to the backlight bleeding effect that some monitor can have. You can imagine something like this: https://s2.qwant.com/thumbr/0x380/7/3/0c38d59954880e31d99e12b43f748a4bf344148e6ec20558eae3c6c3f8eee1/backlight.jpg?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tabbloidx.co%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2F2019%2F08%2Fbacklight.jpg&q=0&b=1&p=0&a=0 but more grid like. So a grid that at the edges has a similar effect at the backlight effect and inside the grid the cells were not very regular.

All those patterns would come and go depending on where I looked on the screen and how open my eyes were. They also felt cyclic, but I am not sure.

I don't know if this information could help you as well, but I did the experience with this monitor: 
- AOC C24G1, 144Hz

column10: At first I saw nothing but the flickering light. Shapes then began to immerge out of the ether of the color field. They were not colored as I found the red immensely distracting. The shapes then began to take on geometry morphing into each other with low amounts of control over the apertures. The geometries swung around with great energy the entire field of the color swinging inward and outward and all around like double doors not bound to natural laws. The geometry then began to form into people. They were all tainted with red but their structures were well defined. I remember a skull spinning around haphazardly with great structural detail. All the structures were geometrically idealized lacking in texture and in formal color other than that of a sort of middle hue of washed out red. It was in this state of figures that I closed my eyes for a few moments to recover somewhat and saw an intensely vivid geometric strata like that of Islamic tile work in stunning saphire and baby blues with black lines emphasizing the structure and the color of the geometry radiating outward from a central point. When I looked at the screen again I recognized the geometry of the wheel spoke pattern but washed out and with no color. I then looked away from the screen and the wood of the desk I was centered in was melting into rainbow. In this moment I was quite uncomfortable and decided that it was probably best for me to finish the experience early. I did this in a library so I could not play the white noise, it was not dark, and there was minor noise pollution. I decided it was probably best for me not to try to repeat this experiment under more ideal circumstances as I found it quite strenuous on my mind and eyes.

column10: Again, the dominant color of the screen alternated, somewhat frustratingly.  While it was red, green cells grew out of the lower right and left corners.  the cells were various shades of blue-green.  While the screen was black-dominant, there were bright yellow fractal patterns across everything, but with a centerpoint that would move with my eyes.  The centerpoint often had either an X or a cross streaking out from it (I think this may have actually been related to the pixels on my monitor).  Often there would be large, darkened circle around the centerpoint as well, although not necessarily centered on it.  Think Death Star or Technodrome.  Over the 10 minutes, the yellow in this field would gradually become the dominant color.  for a short time, the center point receded on the z-axis and became a winding tunnel, which I was imagining flying into.

column10: At first I just saw lines and arcs.  After that, colors started to appear in little explosions like fireworks.  Then, what appeared to be a snake or Chinese dragon like creature started to show up for a few moments at a time, curling in the shape of a lemniscate in the center of the screen.  From there, I saw what could have been a dark room, but that only lasted for a moment and I only assume it to have been a room based on what seemed like potential edges in the periphery.  Finally, I saw the same lemniscate-like shape, but without a snake-like creature.  Just the lemniscate itself, almost pulsing along its own shape.  The pulses were fast, but definitely followed the shape as they occurred.  In the final moments of the 10 minute time period, the red of the flickering screen faded almost completely and became much darker, like my vision when stepping into a dark place from a light one.  There were ball-like shapes of color in the darkness, but not in a discernable pattern or in meaningful positions.

column16: The experience was somewhat tense and anxious at the start.  The flicker eventually started to lull me into a more relaxed, sleepy state, and the anxiety faded almost completely.  However, I was still fairly alert and cognizant of the time spent on the experience.

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black, sometimes the simple shapes lined up in a way where i could pretend it was something else (crop dusting airplane viewed from above, car going over a bridge and under streetlights viewed from diagonally above), but it was more in a cloudgazing kind of way than a real imagery kind of way
column10:
at first i saw a kind of circle pattern where there was a ring around where i was looking that wasnt blinking - only stayed black.
there was a lot of rotation. sometimes there was a line that was rotating. each side of the line was also rotating - almost looked like two very large gears were meeting, but also their axles were rotating around each other.
that line would expand sometimes and look more complicated
occasionally triangles or pentagons would show up. sometimes i couldnt see the whole shape.
any time i moved my eyes i lost what i was seeing
the only two complex things i saw were a crop dusting airplane and a car crossing a bridge. but i saw them more as a 'simple shapes reminiscent of' than actually seeing them. the airplane for example was a full screen T shape - dark bar across the whole top of the screen and down the whole center. and there was some downwards motion "coming down from the wings" in some way i don't know how to explain. the car was kind of an isometric view going under streetlights and over a bridge, also with motion. but didnt see a car just a kind of isometric cube in motion.
when i closed my eyes there was a very strange pattern on the back of my eyelids. when i opened them again, i saw a pattern of blue and green.
sometimes it looked like there was two zigzag lines opening and closing like a monster's mouth over the entire screen. eventually they lost center and started meeting lower and lower until they were offscreen.
sometimes it looked like a giant industrial fan, or a corkscrew.
sometimes it looked like the camera was going from above an object, over the edge, and flying away keeping a perspective of it, kinda like the 20th century fox intro. i couldnt make out what the object was i just got a sense of motion.

column10: Depending on eye muscles and lid openness, it had a strong influence on patterns seen.  Looking up/left or down/right (etc), would alter the patterns.  Sometimes lasers everywhere, sometimes 4 or 6 huge ones like traveling through space.  Sometimes balls - big & small spinning everywhere.  Sometimes balls with fractal patterns.  Sometimes just dancing lights like small firecrackers.  It was a huge variety of patterns to fill the gaps and make sense of.  It was fun to see the brain attempting to fill the void with such a variety of things.  I'm impressed that it selected fractals in various geometries.
column14: Constant, morphing from one image to the next
column15: As if in a dreamlike state
column16: It was very similar to lucid dreaming.  I could control it to some extent once I had a decent read on the patterns.  And once the eye narrowness or muscles had an obvious effect, I was able to force change by shifting where my eyes looked on the screen or by narrowing one eye, the other, or both.  I cycled through various patterns, but was starting to become bored by the end.  It was relaxing, though.

column15: Felt a little altered and out of it, with spikes of anxiety. I'm often pretty photosensitive--I always like the lights, especially at night, to be dimmer than other people, and I live in sunglasses. So I had some paranoia that I could be hurting myself somehow.

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes)
column10: For the first couple of minutes, I felt like I could see a VERY vague backdrop of interlocking geometric shapes, like the panels of a soccer ball if it were laid out flat. Once that faded, I never really saw any shapes again, though for a while it did kind of feel as though what I was seeing was slightly responsive to the music I was listening to, with redness or blackness seeming to wash over the screen and linger for several seconds when the music reached a dramatic moment. There were times where the bursts of light had a sense of directional movement to them, either moving diagonally or from one side of the screen to the other. Near the end, there was kind of a vague sensation of moving though a tunnel. Overall, viewing the Ganzflicker was a mildly enjoyable experience. Similar to experiences I've had when trying to meditate, the most unpleasant aspect was that I couldn't really get my mind to quiet down.
column15: No change, fully alert in the here and now
column16: My mind stayed very "meta" throughout the whole experience. I kept thinking about what I might have just seen or what I wanted to see or why I might be different from people who do see more intense hallucinations. I think this kind of kept me from having a more conscious altering experience.

column10: For the first few minutes, movement of shapes and colours as though they were travelling through tunnels or along roads, mainly from top right to centre then off bottom right. Later, cartoon-like images, drawn in thin, yellow-coloured scratchy lines. When I blinked or closed then opened my eyes firmly, I could see a plain red screen for a moment.  Mostly the screen was red/ orange/ green flashing, not one colour.  None of the images were clear and none lasted long (lasted a few seconds only).

column10: In the beginning, a honeycomb pattern formed across the screen and sometimes there were blue lines that emerged within that pattern. That visual faded away after a minute or two and then it mostly went back to flashing red. Later, a set of non parallel lines formed across the screen, widest at the right side of the screen and narrowing as it went across the left side of the screen and the two lines seemed to go on forever without ever connecting. The impression was like looking at an image of an infinite train that goes on forever (although I saw no actual imagery of a train). On the right side of the screen, the lines made an imposing figure but then as you followed it to the left, it just tapered off into infinity. For the latter half of the viewing, I cannot describe any specific patterns that arose, but random patterns would emerge and fade out (things like square or diamond patterns across the screen).

column10:
It was a fairly dull experience for a first few minutes. Then, at around 5-ish minutes the black color of the flickering pattern essentially disappeared and was replaced by other colors. They seemed to gradually fade into each other. Mostly yellow, white and blue but short bits of green too. A little bit later I started seeing simple blurry patterns on my screen. Mostly reminiscent of the effect you get when you close your eyes after looking at a light. Like blurry dots, arranged in a circle with lines of dots coming out of it.

Around 8 minutes, the white noise and staring at the screen was starting to get to me and I fell asleep for a hot second. After that I couldn't get back into the effect.

column16: I started feeling increasingly sleepy at around the same time I started seeing visual changes (~5 minutes). Then I fell asleep at around 8 minutes into the flickering, after which the previously described visual effects were gone. Mind you, I did this at 1:30 am, just before going to bed.

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Complex environments (e.g., cityscapes, forests), It would be more accurate to say that I saw "simple environments" - what looked like viewing an ocean from above at night, just a sea of dark waves tipped with moonlight from a light (moon) n the sky. The view from a car window of fields flying past so fast they were little more than a blur.
column10: It would be more accurate to say that I saw "simple environments" - what looked like viewing an ocean from above at night, just a sea of dark waves tipped with moonlight from a light source (the moon) in the sky. The view from a car window of fields flying past so fast they were little more than a blur. In between that it was largely periods of nothing (seeing red an black flashing light), seeing a white light line that tended to bend like a snake or into a moving arc, or a very intense sense of motion being visually perceived that would change directions (sometimes left to right), sometimes swirling like a tornado viewed either from the side or from above. It gave me pretty  awful motion sickness to view, and I had to keep blinking to get rid of the images of motion to keep my stomach from turning too much. The longer you don't blink, the more the complex images seemed to come/form, so my guess is I might have seen more if I wasn't blinking to avoid nausea. The white noise sounds also seemed to worsen the nausea.

column16: At different points, it definitely felt like the stage of sleep where you're just starting to dream, where you believe you're awake, but you're seeing imagery forming in your head and you're slowly sinking into what inevitably becomes a dream. In between that, I felt very relaxed, like my heart rate and breathing had slowed, as did the frequency of my blinking (except when I got nauseous, and that had the reverse effect). Sort of like being in a meditative state.

column10: Mostly I saw the colors moving, like as it changed between black to red, the colors would kind of scroll slowly to the right, like a sideways filmstrip on an old fashioned movie projector, or outward from the center. The only "object" I saw was a couple of pale blue lines, first just one, diagonal, not perfectly straight or very clearly formed, kinda like a blurry lightning bolt, which stayed for several seconds, and then another diagonal the other way, and sometimes both at the same time, but they kind of faded in and out and weren't very clear. Then they went away.

column10: Movement, constantly shifting directions.  Spinning spoked circles that rotated in 3 dimensions as they spun, and occasional wagonwheel effects as they spun.  At one point it was like looking out of a car or train while passing open fields with trees or other tall objects of varying height in the distance background (although I didn't notice any sort of parallax effect).  At one point it was as if I was traveling through some sort of long and winding tunnel -- not unlike the traveling-through-the-wormhole scenes in Stargate: SG-1, although the brightness flickered up and down along the shaft as if there were rings of slight brightness along the length so it was if I was flying through a sort of stripey tunnel.  In all cases, the more concrete and specific something became, the more rapidly it gave way to something else -- whether I was trying to focus on it or simply allow it to happen.  For a period of a minute or so, I also saw a small black dot in the center of my field of vision surrounded by a small splotch of...  faded(?) red of irregular shape.  This dot and splotch would disappear if I moved my eyes until they stopped moving at which point it would re-emerge.  And then at some point it stopped but I don't recall if this was sudden or gradual.
column14: Constant, morphing from one image to the next
column15: As if in a dreamlike state, Felt transported to another place
column16: Despite being fully, consciously aware of and connected to my body and immediate surroundings, there was a sense of being... I'm not sure.  Dazed, perhaps?  Disoriented?  And of floating through an abstract space.  It stood out to me during the time that it seemed like I should have more trouble with proprioception given how I was feeling.  I can confirm my proprioception _was_ working properly though:  I was laying on my back with the laptop balanced on my chest, and using my arms to blot out the sides of my field of vision and the macOS menu bar (to reduced light intrusion even more), so I had to make adjustments fairly continuously.   I had a definite sense that once this ended I would be _very_ disoriented for at least a solid minute or more.  That sense proved largely wrong:  Once the experience ended, the sense of disorientation mostly subsided within a few seconds.  I still have a certain background fuzziness I'm feeling right now, like you might have 10 minutes after going on a very intense roller coaster ride.
