column10: None of it was really quite clear, this is my interpretation of the very vague visuals I saw. At first, it was like a mirrored reflection of what looked like forests and mountains, then I saw what looked like the silhouette of a man sitting with his legs crossed and what looked like a star on his forehead. Then, he picks up a bow and arrow and shoots it off into the distance. My vision follows the "arrow", which just looked like streaks across the screen. When the "arrow" hit, the spot where it hit turned into a singular eye. After a few seconds, there were what seemed like thousands of eyes rotating around and spiraling into the one eye I saw then. I stopped viewing after a few minutes of eyes rotating around this one eye.

column10: Periodic zoom in of a rainbow-colored clockwise rotating fissure that opened like lips. Either side of the fissure was like a random waveform. At the beginning of each period, the fissure was pressed together closely - about 1/2 inch separating the waveform boundaries. As the fissure rotated clockwise, (usually from a diagonal starting point -- about 135 degrees), the colors would disappear and the boundaries would expand as if zooming in and form nodes of white light that moved to the periphery. Then, a new period would begin with a new rainbow colored fissure starting a new rotation. Throughout, zones of gray were pulsing in round shapes at the extremes of the screen.

column10: Primarily I was seeing shapes and patterns flickering. At one point, maybe halfway through, I had a really strong sensation that I was flying over the ocean on a bright day. I wasn't actually "seeing" the image, I just had a strong clear picture of it in my mind, as if I were remembering it. The sun was shining off the water and as I moved through the sky, the placement of the sun would move. It was always along the top of the screen, and then there were lines of it reflecting off the water below me. It lasted for maybe a minute or two and then I went back to the shapes and patterns flickering. The shapes and patterns reminded me of a kaleidoscope or old psychedelic 1970s art. I did truly see other colors than red and black, including orange and blue as parts of the patterns.

column10: The images were constant from the start, over the whole screen. It looked like shifting hexagons at first, like a 2-dimensional honeycomb sliding around. Then it was almost like it turned into a 3D honeycomb snake, moving back and forth and in and out of the screen. Then, at some point it turned into slightly textured surfaces shifting back and forth, like a map of the moon. Then the snake came back. The initial honeycomb never came back. In addition to red and black, I saw blue.

column10:
The most vivid visualizations were like spinning gears or maybe equipment you might ascribe to space ship engine. When my eyes focused they would spin for a bit before going out of focus. The would appear in any variety of orientations but were all fairly large, disappearing at the edge of the screen. 

Sometimes there were warp tunnels. So it would look like I were moving forward through something you would imagine for sci-fi, like the Doctor Who intro except less nebulous. Sometimes it would be straight ahead or seem to bend around a corner. They would generally still feel like they were rotating about the axis of motion.

Visualization become much less common after auditory stimulation ended

column10:
=== permanent ===

a red and dark green checkerboard, with a cross in the middle. the checkerboard will turn into other two-tone interlacing.

=== often ===

streaks or dots of color: white, yellow, light green, blue.

=== once each ===

the screen carved itself.

Fishes: In the first half of the video, green spots started to look like a big cartoonish blue fish. the other spots started to look like silhouettes of fish.

the two dragons: at the start of the second half, the chessboard looked like a pole of clouds. Suddenly, a vermiform devil-headed monster was trying to get out of a cloud, with difficulty. another shows, dragon-headed imitated him. these watches radiated malevolence.

the great dragon:
I had the impression of watching a damaged film, the ganzflickter being a filter in front of the image. a large scaly dragon was on the screen, slowly walking to the right of the screen and was going to go out of the frame. this dragon was worse than the firsts. malicious, he was powerful and above all sneaky.
I was afraid he would attack me. to reassure myself, I voluntarily came out of my trance by voluntarily moving my eyes.
column11: 1-2 minutes, 5-7 minutes, l'échiquier est apparu immédiatement. il a fallu attendre plus de 4 minutes pour que les poissons apparaissent. les trois dragons sont apparus peut après. plus le temps passait, plus les visions étaient concrètes. une histoire se développait.

column10: A face, that I would stereotypically described as the Joker, with a large smile and pointy nose that would start out small and grow to fill the entire screen and then repeat. I was uncomfortable with that repeating image and attempted to control what I was seeing and was able to change the image to spiraling light patterns, which is close to what I intended, which was a galaxy. It started to feel enjoyable, almost like in a free space to create, but I started feeling slight nausea from the spinning imagery and decided to stop.
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy, As if in a dreamlike state, Felt transported to another place
column16: Once I consciously engaged with the imagery that appeared in an attempt to change what I was seeing, having chose to do so because the initial imagery of a spiraling Joker face was slightly uncomfortable, I could sense that I held less tension in my body posture and felt as if I could continue to dive deeper into the imagery and create new things. It seemed like I was able to influence what I was seeing to an extent, but there was always a continuous spiraling aspect to the imagery that was causing gradually increasing amounts of nausea and uncomfortableness. I don't think I lost a sense of time because I knew 10 minutes was the amount of time I had to complete the experience, which I did not due to feeling too nauseous.

column10: A lot of different shapes - hexagons, octogons, squares, circles, triangles, oblong shapes with sharp edges. One image looked almost like a tiny neon UFO and appeared on the right upper side of the screen first, then the very center, then the left upper side of the screen.

column15: I felt slightly panicked.
column16: My ears started ringing really hard during the experience, and I started to feel like I do at the beginning of my body kicking into fight or flight. Additionally, the ringing in my ears was getting intense and I started to feel a headache coming on and became slightly nauseated - this is the same response my body has when I become motion sick, and I am uncertain if this is somehow related. Typically, when these symptoms occur, it leads to a migraine, and between this and the ringing ears, I felt panicked and had to stop the experience early.

column9: Distortions (e.g., screen warping or rotating), Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black, In some of the darker areas, what looked like dappled shading of leaves on a tree or a star field.
column10: A lot of red flickering, began with a giant snowflake pattern against the red.  It expanded out like a kaleidoscope, but less colorful.  It throbbed and spun and flickered.  There were sometimes rapid "explosions" or pulsing that would move across the screen, mostly red/yellow.  Sometimes the pulses would have darker areas where I could almost see something like nondescript leaves on a tree - colorless like trees at night, but their shapes outlined by the moonlight, sometimes smaller light spots like a starfield.  There was sometimes a rapid rotation.  [more things I can't remember]  Towards the end I saw what looked like eyelashes of a pair of closed eyes, dark on a bright red/orange/yellow gradient background.   there were either two eyes at first and then multiple smaller eyes, or first multiple smaller eyes and then ended with just two large eyes.  I'd like to try it again with a darker room.  The lights are out and curtains closed, but it's still daylight coming through the window on the door and on the staircase.  Maybe not today, though!  It was rough at first but got easier.

column15: I don't think I can even describe it.
column16: My mind seemed more able to drift away toward the end.  I was startled out of it when the white noise stopped suddenly.  It actually seemed louder when the white noise ended.  I definitely was not sleepy, but I think maybe it became easier to imagine things, if I had thought to try imagining things instead of trying to watch the shapes.  Maybe I did lose a sense of time - it did not seem like 10 minutes, but nothing dramatic.

column10: As soon as it started I saw Pepe the frog (not a joke). I often saw eyes, the number 4, triangles, sometimes the number 3, some snakes, mice, cats (usually the face of a mouse or cat, usually more as if they were drawn than as a photo). I saw kind of a suggestion of a landscape, tall building out near the ocean on a hill, but it wasn't really vivid or colored in, just flicker colored. The color of the actual flicker would change also, started out mostly red, I saw a lot of yellow or orange and sometimes a more vivid red, occasionally it could be green. If I watched the center usually it looked like pulses in the shape of a triangle would start there and expand out to fill the screen, but sometimes there would be a crease in the middle like a book where the pages come together and that would make the two sides of the screen seem to curve like a big paperback book's pages will if you're near the middle of reading it. Sometimes the outside edges of the screen would look really wavy, like the flicker didn't fill the screen anymore. It seemed like if I wanted to see something in it I could, but I tried not to think anything up on my own and just watch it. I didn't really know it could do anything auditory, I listened to the white noise and didn't really focus on that.

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black, Complex objects (e.g., animals, faces, buildings), Writing, numbers, short animated sequences, religious imagery eg tall angels glowing gold and green), demonic faces, jagged spikes, what looked like lines in the sand, swirling, paisley-like
column10: At first it looked like a "negative image" of geometric (Aztec or Babylonian style) ziggurats, triangles, thick black lines, a bit like the Opticians red and green with black lines, "which is clearer, left or right, and now? And now?".... Then I saw a big black "X" stretching to all four corners of the screen. Then a sort of fingerprint, ribbed lines, sworls in wet sand type patterns that sometimes looked like they were turning into a pair of eyes as drawn in pencil; or a horse's mane; or stylised, pencil-drawn paisley-like swirls. (I used to doodle these type of patterns endlessly as a teenager and they're still my automatic doodle whenever I'm on autopilot on the telephone!) Then the "eye" whorls started to become a bit sinister, demonic, very intense, and I got a bad, nightmare sort of feeling. Which surprised me as I have a long history of hallucinogen use, and Bipolar1 occasional psychoses, so I was shocked a mere visual illusion could evoke such "hallucinatory" type feelings as well as images - the nightmarish sense of dread... But just as a jagged, dense black spiky "fringe" of hair started emerging above the "eyes", it suddenly shifted to "fingerprints" surrounded by vague, faint "writing" (handwritten, rather old-fashioned ink-and-quill handwriting) which reassured me to continue, till eventually, just before the end, two giant ie from top to bottom of the entire screen, looming figures developed - beginning as flickering black figure of 8's, till they seemed to be giants the bodies much larger than the "distant, faraway, high up" heads; then a green glow was around the body areas like long glowing deep green robes, and a gold and silverish glow started to surround their distant heads like rather warped, shapeless, vague "haloes", and I understood them to be traditional, Biblical Angels - that is, not cuddly cherubim or gentle guardian angels of modern iconography, but terrifying, awe inspiring angels, like Rilke's Duino Elegies - awesome: monolithic; inscrutable, unimaginably powerful. None of these images were detailed, or photographic quality. As much of it was "felt" as it was "seen". Hope this helps your research.

I often get these "felt tastes" during drug experiences? Never been able to find out what they are!!

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black, Complex environments (e.g., cityscapes, forests), Writing: typewritten words and numbers
column10: At the start, I clearly saw floating typewritten words, but I could not read them.  They were moving around on the screen and I could not focus on any to make out what they were saying.  After about 30 seconds, they dissappeared and were replaced by flashing colors - mostly yellow and dark blue, and a pattern that varied between the outlines of leaves and one with a six pointed figure in the middle lighter than the rest of the screen, like a snowflake shape. These flashing lights and patterns made up the majority of my experience. In the middle, I got two flashes of "scenes"; one was an outdoor scene with green grass and light blue, slightly cloudy sky, the other was a night time scene of a stage with lights and a crowd in front of it - like a rock concert.  Each scene lasted for a split second and was gone.  These were the only two items I could make out.  It seemed like other pictures were flashing occasionally, but I could not make out clearly what they were.  At the very end, I saw some flashes that looked like lightning bolts and decided I was a little uncomfortable and wanted to stop.  This was almost exactly 10 minutes in.

column16: In the beginning, I felt a little uncomfortable, my chest felt tight and I felt slightly anxious, but I continued. I wasn't very conscious of the passage of time - not a clue how long I had been staring, but I remembered that the white noise tape was 10 minutes long.  It seemed like a much longer time had passed.

column10: During the first 90% of watching, I was seeing bright lines, mainly two of them froming a cross, with the impression that there was a flow inside each line and the cross was randomly rotating. Then after a while, new lines appeared and disappeared randomly. and After a while I was able to generate one line and control the direction of rotation (but not the speed at which it rotated). Then in the very end, I started seeing sort of bubbles of lights, different sizes but mainly small ones, with some colors like blue, yellow and green, and after a while those bubbles were forming the lines that I was seeing earlier and moving inside of those line as a constant flow. After I stopped watching the screen, I closed my eyes and I was seeing a beautiful pattern of blue dots all over my eyes, equally spaced and all same size, moving a bit and this impression lasted for a minute or two.

column10: First encountered a black band moving up the screen and focused on it.  Once the band was removed the black pulse was replaced with a teal blue color and the red became orange nearly yellow. Vortex images appeared  moving in a counter clockwise screw-like pattern. Timing of the flashing modified and white balls of light being fired at me in a 3-D effect appeared. Flashing modified again and the imagery became reminiscent of the color flashes I see when dreaming.  Obscure moving imagery appeared in disjointed shapes and sizes and a variety of colors similar to fireworks.  Black color band reappeared and gave me a point to focus on.  Once the band was removed the image of driving very fast in a tiled tunnel came into focus.  That subsided and the vortex screw like imagery reappeared.  The white noise ceased and my 10 minutes were up.

column10: First I saw multiple Xs which morphed into lightning and electricity, which morphed into spiderwebs, which morphed into ovals. Many times they were exact dual images (exact mirrors of each other, right next to each other, e.g. double Xs, double ovals, double lighting). And about 2 min in I saw a tree with branches reaching down to the bottom, like a Christmas tree. After the first 5 min I had a lot of trouble seeing anything, so for the last 5 min I was trying to see things but could no longer make out distinct images. But I did see green instead of red after the 5 min mark.

column10: First it was like MC Escher tessellation patterns, like a warped checkerboard. Then sometimes the pattern would spin. Sometimes a skinny abstract gargoyle was flying through a crudely shaped scape of dead trees on a flat plane, with the "camera" following right behind the gargoyle. And sometimes it was just a simple flashing red and black screen, but with a blurry cross shape in the middle, of alternating colors, that followed the center of my vision. Basically, once I started seeing something, the visualizations never regressed back to just a plain red and black screen.

column10: Good luck.  It was like reading a manga/comic strip, but the light and dark were two different sets of stories/environments and the screen kept flashing between them.  Every now and again it would morph back to the geometric shapes in a flying or repeating pattern before a new set of imagery would appear.  Quite cool.  The dark set of images were like negatives, but it wasn't just black and white, more like a grey-blue on black.  The dark scenes were more lined (sharp angles, almost like iron filings taking shapes).  The bright scenes were orange to red and more rounded in shape or straight up geometric.  The orange/red/bright predominated.  The dark scenes were almost always noir like.

column10: I began to see geometric patterns almost instantly. Over time, those patterns morphed into a pair of spheres that grew and shrank as they rotated around each other and moved across the screen. As the spheres continued to rotate colors beyond red and black began to emerge, primarily greens and blues...although the dominant color of the experience was red.
column14: Constant, morphing from one image to the next
column15: Lost a sense of time, Slight anxiety inducing or nervousness, as if at the start of psychedelic trip.
column16: I was calmish throughout, but could feel a mild anxiety...that feeling of being at the top of the rollercoaster you get when you decide to embark on a psychadelic trip. Its not entirely unpleasant, just an awareness that something could happen that's beyond your control. I may return to this experiment later and complete the full 10 mins to see how that changes the feelings and outcomes.

column8: Enjoyable, didn't want it to stop
column9: Distortions (e.g., screen warping or rotating), Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Complex objects (e.g., animals, faces, buildings), I saw white stars on a black background, not sure if that counts as another colour
column10:
I didn’t realise there was a link to white noise on the e-mail so I just went on Utube and then got side tracked by the different coloured noises available and reading a bit about each of them.
I actually went with Grey noise as that seemed (according to studies on noise) to be a better balance of noise rather than white noise I had a good listen in the dark and was probably in danger of going to sleep so cranked up the Ganzflicker.  It was good almost straight away, felt like a river of energy flowing past you mostly coming towards me out of the screen from one corner and then the other that alternated in swirls and other patterns that were all pretty organic.  I felt I could go deeper and every time I blinked it seemed to start back with the flashing lights and then into some cool stuff then I had to blink again and start all over.
Im not sure why but I thought it was the grey noise so I went out and to the link and did the white noise.  That changed things remarkably which I thought was interesting, the shapes and patterns became much more geometric and im gunna say logical for lack of a better word, but I saw stuff like a double helix and lots of squares with slightly rounded edges (like calculator buttons) in a multitude of rapidly repeating patterns and flows that spun and twisted and reformed it was very very cool and very enjoyable.
Then it changed up and was back to this river type feeling and it felt like I was standing in the edge of it with most of it flowing past me but a bit going behind me as well.  I actually felt a bit anxious that I might get swept away and then I started to see stuff in the river flowing down stream at speed, A guy on a horse Cowboy like the Winchester gun logo  sort of set up and then i saw Buffalo running in a herd.  They appeared as like a black pencil sketch or etching against the red river. 
I also heard dolphins, couldn't see them but sort of felt they were there in the river and knew where they were, you could sort of see the swirling they made underneath the swirling of the river so I could see where they were under the surface but they just didn’t really show themselves. 
Also saw stars, white stars on a black background, that was really weird as mostly everything I had see to that point was on a red background so when the red went away (it sorted faded to the side of my vision) and I saw the black and the stars I thought I may have closed my eyes without realising it, but I blinked and re opened then and it was red again for a second and then the black and the stars showed themselves again.
It felt like I had sort of stuck my head through the rushing red river and out the other side where it was quieter and you could see the sky and the stars.  Remined me of movie 2001 when Dave looks inside the monolith and says its full of stars.
I was doing this lying in bed and by this stage was so relaxed I was struggling to hold the laptop so ended it there.
column12: Frequently, really only saw the cowboy and the Buffalo as images the rest was shapes and 3d swirls and son on.  but i saw them a few times and they were moving, running legs going or at least the impression of them running
column13: Weak, faint, or insubstantial, Clear and moderately vivid, the images were 3d but set back in the screen, the river and the shapes however were all around me at times
column14: Persisting several seconds, Constant, morphing from one image to the next
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy, Lost a sense of space, I found i had lost any perception of how i was sitting and holding the laptop and i was very relaxed and happy, not really sleepy
column16: Not a change of consciousness i felt very very close to that when i saw the stars, i very much wanted to push through the red river and see the stars better, i was very happy and at ease.  I began willing myself to do so but i couldn't and it felt like my body reconnected and i felt sleepy and the weight of the laptop and my arm tiring and I ended the session.  maybe in retrospect it was slightly like my mind wanted to go through but my body wasn't so keen to do so..?
column17: All over the screen, They tended to move within the river usually running against the current

column10: I didn't see anything at first, but then I started seeing plaid patterns. Later, the patterns differed. Sometimes the two intersecting lines forming the patterns turned into bright purple-pink. After a while, I was immersed in my own thoughts and imagination. Some parabolic patterns briefly changed to the rings of Saturn and Jupiter. I could see them for 2-3 seconds. Towards the end, 4-5 vertically side-by-side oval objects suddenly turned into spots on Jupiter, and they suddenly began to sway left and right with a glitch effect, as if they had entered a bug, which was short-lived. The last thing I remember was a devilish smiley face from the comic book version of The Joker, which may be because in the comments of the YouTube video that led me to this test, some people said they saw the Joker, so I might have been under their influence and saw the Joker through such an expectation.

column10: I saw a long tunnel, then a sun appeared at the end of it. It pulsed then exploded. Then it reappeared along with another sun. They circled each other. Then more suns appeared, all circling each other before they all exploded. Then the view went dark and I couldn't see much red, only occasionally. After that I saw a right lung coalesce before it faded, then a heart (the organ, not the valentine) appeared and faded. Then I saw geometric kaleidoscope shapes that were dynamic, with light pulses moving from the center outward very quickly. Then it ended.

column10:
I saw very clearly a blurred checkerboard. It also looked like ripples were coming out of the corners of the screen. Which, if you look at a ripple tank simulation, creates a blurred checkerboard.

See https://www.falstad.com/ripple/, with "Four Sources", but the sources were the corners instead of left / top / right / bottom, and the waves were red and black. That's exactly what I saw.

I also kind of saw the "fan of lazers" and felt like I was going inside the screen.

At the same time though, I was very aware that the Ganzflicker was just red and black over and over. All of the visions (even the waves / checkerboard) weren't very strong or overpowering, and I could see them and the actual Ganzflicker simultaneously.

column10: I was running(flying?) Through a wooded mountainside and stopped at a huge hollowed out tree stump that was about 11 foot in diameter and about 8.5 feet tall, the wood was charred and was separating from itself along the top, there was only one triangular entrance and I walked through it and when I entered there was already a small fire lit. A tea kettle was placed on top of a decent sized rock in the middle of the fire and then the smoke from the fire started swirling out in every direction. Everything in my field of view became hazy and a raven appeared perched atop the entrance. Its beaks parted with a loud yet comforting "squaw" that rang(echoed?) Out for multiple seconds before becoming distorted and sounding as if I were suddenly thrust underwater. There was then bright glowing orbs dancing above where the fire was and it seemed as if I was now being pulled up into the air.(maybe I began to levitate slowly.)

column10: I wouldn't really call them images so much as like... the colors you see in your eyes if you rub them too hard or look into a bright light. Maybe that's not a universal experience, but it's the only way I can really describe it. They mostly appeared as geometric shapes, blurry blue lines on a red background, kind of a repeating ikat pattern. Near the end, I began seeing small white dots - think the static on an old TV. There weren't many, but they were in clusters of maybe 4 to 6. There were probably a half dozen clusters on the screen that moved around. The visuals also changed the audio experience. It sounded as if there was a pulsing bass sound over the white noise.

column10:
It started as simple shapes/ lights turning on themselves then turning in long corridors/elevator shaft through witch a was going really fast. The lights on the 4 corners turn from flashing to long straight lines sometimes turning sometimes remaining straight. 

Then was laying on my back in the back of a moving cart in the middle of a road in a forest at night, then I caught a glimpse of the moon through the clouds the moon the turned into a white face that split open in the middle where another face, this time golden, emerged and left a trail like a shouting star behind it. The trail started wavering and the turned into a golden road leading to castle far in the distance. I was transported to door of said castle immediately and the doors open to a bright white light.

Repeat. It was like as soon as my mind began to relax into it and shapes began to form I snapped back into awareness. My brain refused to let go. Frustrating. I wish the article that led me here hadn't told me what others had described because it led to overthinking and disappointment. Experience did remind me of having my eyes closed on a car trip, with the sunlight flashing through objects we passed, illuminating the dark behind my lids to red.

column10:
Mostly, just a flashing red and black screen. At times, those resolved into grids and circles, or the impression the screen was bulging.

Once, they briefly appeared to be a simplistic image of a fire truck raising a ladder. Once, a butterfly (again, simplistic). Once, a skull.

column15: Somewhat drawn away from my usual mind.
column16:
I felt as though the flashing light wanted me to watch it (to be very clear: I did *not* feel as though I considered it to have a consciousness of its own), or that I felt entirely compelled to do so.

I was also, at the same time, quite bored, but (through a roughly equal mix of wishing to commit to the experiment, and said feeling of compulsion) felt unable to look away, though I did wish that the time would pass faster.

Purely for reference: when I encounter strobe lighting in a theatre, the best description of my mental response I have been able to come up with is "it feels as though the light is trying to kill me" - again, not to ascribe it an actual mind, merely that I feel as though it has a great deal of menace and has somehow taken control of *my* mind. I am aware this is not entirely regular, though have not yet been to see a doctor for any diagnosis that might actually make this a useful point of reference to you, as it is a rather manageable state of affairs.

I have mild ADHD, so it took a lot to concentrate and be "absorbed" by the flicker. My mind would constantly bounce back out and I'd have to recenter it.

Lasted 8 minutes. Mild headache afterwards but not sure if that's psychosomatic

column10: Saw rectangles, lots of rectangles. When I was looking at the top of the screen (as if I were going to read an email), the rectangles sometimes seemed to be like chasing lights that you see on houses during the holidays. In other words, the brightness seemed to progress across the screen but was more dramatic (brighter) in the middle of the screen.  When I changed to look at the middle of the screen, it was more uncomfortable on my eyes (like I had a sinus headache).  Then, the left and right edges of the monitor seemed to curl in a bit.  I didn't see any images, but then again, my mind is a frenzied chipmunk (ADD) and I didn't expect to see anything.  My guess is that people who can meditate without falling asleep will have better luck than I.  All the best!

column10: Shapes, circles, squares, stars and waves moving around the screen. In the beginning mostly swirling and drifting around, later moving in a rippling pattern. Sometimes something resembling eyes or faces briefly flashed in the view, the kind you'd see in Deep Learning glitch art. A few times I had a feeling that a silhouette of a car moved by, or a Totoro appeared. The experience was disturbing and uncomfortable to the eyes, but at the same time hypnotizing and hard to stop, until the white noise stopped and I snapped out. I relaxed, my breathing slowed to barely any at all, I almost never blinked. The screen often appeared to expand and I felt compelled to lean closer. Sometimes the periphery of the screen appeared to change into blue or yellow lines. The images outside of the screen (i.e. the dim room) were as if covered in cobwebs or like looking through a shattered glass. Sometimes I felt as if in the white noise there was some music, like doom metal over a quiet poorly tuned radio.

column10:
Started out almost immediately seeing a force field / pulsating grid converging on the horizon. Vanishing point would follow the center of my vision. After a minute or so I started to see flickers of blue and yellow (are certain sub pixels able to turn off faster on my LCD maybe?). Eventually (maybe 5 minutes in) the image became more hallucinatory and less of an artifact, it started to feel like I was in a form of train or elevator car that was rotating at a very high speed (like the flickering was every time I caught a gimps of daylight perhaps). I told myself to have it spin the opposite direction and was able to visualize that, too, so I don't think it had anything to do with monitor refresh rate. My imagination reminded me of a carousel and I started to visualize being on one in a clean city park with buildings across the road and looking down a T-intersection in my center of vision. Then I started to imagine a train ride again; but instead of it rotating, I was seeing the track bend left and right, alternating, while I "looked out the front window". At this point I didn't think my brain would be doing anything fancier/trippier, so I closed my eyes out of curiosity and found the flicker to more absolute in my vision but less intense, so it didn't seem to have the same effect.

Also noticed that my eyes watered and felt warm. The former was likely because I wasn't blinking enough; but the latter I wonder if it was related to bloodflow to my eyes trying to maintain a focus on an item that wasn't there, because I could almost feel some strain as well.

By the end they had disappeared and the red and black pulsating became more of a flow and the screen was more red than black and smooth but not solid.

column10: A dozen or so white beacons would rotate in tandem as if attached to an invisible 3D structure, the occurred a few times in the first 5 minutes and was overlaid on the flashing colors. Constantly saw colors other than red and black. Visual field would be overlaid with a variety of geometry from grids, circles, or blooms. Also would see a small circle of distorted grey ‘smoke’ in the center of my vision if I intentionally looked deeper into the screen as if it were 3D. Have experienced the same thing before encountering hypnagogic imagery. After watching the flicker I closed my eyes and saw a small structure to my right that I couldn’t identify but seemed to be like looking down onto a space as if it were illuminated by moonlight. This faded after 10 seconds and my field was dominated by intertwining transparent green tendrils that had fractal qualities and moved. The smokey distortion was present in the center. Visuals slowly faded after about 3 minutes

column10: A few times, for a half second or so, I saw images of a large city like Manhattan, but from above the skyscrapers, and very quickly the "telephoto" lens zoomed out. Also there were moments of fractal-ish spiderwebs. I wanted those to continue, but they didn't. I realized my mind could make very basic images move left to right and back, up and down. I experimented by blinking my eyes and one thing I thought was weird was an interrupted, blank moment before the mostly red, sometimes black and rarer times blue colors floated around. I wanted it all to be far more trippy, and when it wasn't happening it felt like doing meditation again after not doing it for a long time: too much "monkey chatter" but here: too much chaos in visual field. Not enough smooth organization that developed into anything. I'd start to get there...but then I'd be back to where I started. Also: I think I may have had too much caffeine in my system and that might have hindered the advent of psychedelic imagery that I had desired.

column10: An X that was either red or black, depending on when I regained focus on it. The X split into six arms at one point then back to four. Sometimes it shattered into something of a grid, though in diamonds rather than squares. The diamonds shattered more and began to spin in place. If I retained this focused-unfocused state long enough, I saw blue spiral arms in the background, similar to a spiral galaxy but only the arms in a single line of points like stars. At this point I would lose focus and go back to the X. I tried for 1-2 minutes, but it became very uncomfortable to watch. It took several attempts at starting to get that far.

column10: At the beginning I saw shapes similar to cumulus clouds that remained even after closing my eyes; Then I began to see a triangle in the center that was formed or pulse, followed by a vortex rotating to the center of the screen many times, if I concentrated a little, I could change its direction, but after that it disappeared in a short time, already in the second 10 minute set sometimes the vortex would move and I would see it horizontally as a galaxy; At the extremes, I sometimes saw spots or circles pulsing,  that were followed by an apparent growth on the screen, which was the most vivid thing I felt; Also in the second set I could see an inverted triangle in the center or both triangles, the straight and the inverted at the same time pulsing but when I closed my eyes I saw small triangles all over the place; Also when the electric saw start in the background of my neighborhood I was a little scared at first, coming to believe I saw lines with spikes on the screen, but then the sound of the saw did not seem unpleasant to me; and as an extra I saw some squares, a cross and circles from time to time feeling only once the sensation of depth with some vertical lines that I saw.

column10:
At the start there were grid like patterns, a couple mins more and a rainbow structure (stripes) appeared. The rainbow structure flipped sides and doubled as time went on, when it doubled it usually bent around a blueish purple bullseye. Main colors on rainbow (excluding the red and black flashing) was a mix of yellow, green, and blue. Occasionally the rainbow would shift to a hyperbolic type pattern with similar colors and then fade back to flashing.
Towards midpoint my vision split and became unfocused this happened until the end. The edges of the screen swayed and shifted throughout the experience. Near end my vison started to flicker in sync with the pulse.
Spider web type networks appeared occasionally, but only showed up for a few moments before fading

column10: behind' the flashing pattern, there was a starfield, rotating counterclockwise.  I was able to correct the spin and stabilize, then rotate the view to the right.  There were two roughly spherical objects, one further away in the upper left, one closer in the lower right.  There were waving yellow tendrils coming out of both objects and one tendril persistently  connected the two objects.  The upper left object had greyer coloration with hard angles and protrusions on it, the lower right was more of a tan/yellow color and fairly smooth.  I closed one eye at a time, and the starfield started spinning again, but the stars were only visible from my left eye.  The spheres and tendrils were only visible in my right eye, which could not see the starfield imagery or the 'spin'; the spheres positions were static relative to the starfield whether it was spinning or not.

column10: Bisecting horizontal and vertical light bars that moved left to right across the screen changing in direction then morphing into other 3-D shapes with texture, cloud like mound forms, fire across the bottom of the screen, landscapes of large grassy fields surrounded by rocks, long gravel or dirt pathways edged with stones, concrete and brick angular structures that initially looked like the first several stories of an old castle that had never been completely built or that had suffered damage such that upper floors or roof structures were missing. These ancient-looking structures morphed into what looked more like a midcentury-modern school (one story glass and brick box-like structure in the center of the screen); waves like tidal waves moving right to left across the screen, flashes of words in bold capital print like headlines mixed with overlapping times news print pages with paragraphs with words right side up and upside down. The words generally were not readable as they overlapped other paragraphs and images, though occasionally a word stood out (eg. “Watch”, familiar names) in my left lower field of vision that moved left to right to the center then disappeared. Vague formations that looked like monster faces or fantastical or cartoonish heads that were large and blob-like in my center right field of vision. These were static images that lasted a few seconds. Always swirling gyroscope spirals of red, black and toward the end purple fractals and strands.
column11: 1-2 minutes, 5-7 minutes, The geomatics and fractals were immediate followed by blob-like spherical shapes that became heads and faces. This lasted several minutes then more distinct landscape and building-like structures and words began to emerge.
column12: Infrequently, Frequently, Infrequently at first, but as they became more distinct and I was less shocked by them, they seemed to linger and more gradually morph into other shapes. This became a continuous process such that the last few minutes were all imagery overlapping, coming and going amidst and sort of underneath the constant spiraling swirls and fractals of red black and purple

column10:
During the first five minute stretch, I saw an initial ball of light turn into diagonal crossing bars of yellow with maybe a little blue. "behind" these bars were complex and nearly random looking black-and-white patterns. 

During the second, 10 minute session, it began the same way but the bars of light were more vivid and with many colors, and appearing at every angle, and then constantly rotating and crossing over each-other and reforming and dissolving. Around half way through I began to see what seemed like eyes, but then the bars became more intense and overshadowed that effect.

Most interestingly, from around six minutes in until the end, I gained clear conscious control over the angle of the bars: I would "will" there to be a bar of a certain slope, or two crossing bars in a particular orientation, and they would appear as such, before dissolving or rotating unpredictably. I spent that whole time testing this "ability", and was able to make the bars quickly and easily, but more complex shapes never happened as a result of my volition, besides one circle.
column11: They began to emerge immediately, A few seconds
column12: Frequently, Constantly, straight bars of color at all different angles appeared nearly throughout, some other patterns were more intermittent

column10:
Earliest images I saw were the lines and spiderwebs. Their colors were inverting at roughly the same pace as the flicker. I usually saw red, orange and yellow but occasionally it would turn blue-ish. These shapes remind of a time I had a bad trip on marijuana. 

The screen seemed to expand from the pixels to the bevels of the monitor (~0.5 inches). It took roughly 4 seconds to complete, slowing down near the end. This happened every time I blinked. 

Then I saw grids. The grid was slowly rotating clockwise. Eventually it turned into several circles which rotated the same direction but faster. This is around where the significant color imagery occurred. The whole screen seemed to go through the most of the color wheel aside from the lighter, less vibrant and darker colors (e.g. light blue, purple, but not blue). 

I would cycle through all the above, and I noticed the rotating balls would go faster if I focused on four mid-corners of the screen (not too close to the screen corners). 

I eventually saw an eye for a couple seconds but it was nothing too detailed.
column14: Constant, morphing from one image to the next
column15: Became relaxed or sleepy, As if in a dreamlike state, Felt transported to another place
column16:
Earlier I mentioned a bad trip on marijuana. I remember panicking thinking it would last forever. When I'm sober, it's rare but not unusual for me to think about the concept of afterlife, in the sense that if it was "enjoyable" and eternal, would it ever stop being "enjoyable" because of the length of exposure. It makes no sense to me to be "forever in bliss" because I don't believe you can have bliss without downtime. It would become your new normal. 

This experience was more relaxed. I didn't feel too bothered by the illusions. It never occurred to me that I could be trapped and I would hate this existence if it lasted forever. For a few moments, it was more like "if this was the only thing on my mind, I would never notice what I was missing out on". Perhaps "ignorance is bliss" is a bit more literal and spiritual than I thought?

column10: Faint circles or bubbles that began to merge together.  If I relaxed my eyes, it looked like the image was rotating, as if I were falling down into a spiraling red tunnel.  I would periodically close my eyes, because the blinking was giving me some mild headaches, but when I opened my eyes, whatever illusion I'd seen before had ended - but a new illusion would replace it.  At one point, it looked like a bright light was shining from the corner of the screen and pulsing into the center of the screen.  I wondered if this is what it felt like to travel on the surface of the sun.  I knew that it's all a simple optical trick, so I wondered if I could control what kinds of images I saw by thinking about specific things and then trying to find them in the flickering, but it didn't work very well.  I could, however, move the center of the spirals around the screen by willing it, and at times, it appeared as if there were two separate vortexes dancing around each other.  Maybe appeared as if there was some yellow mixed in with the red, but it was faint.  At one point, it almost looked like there were fractures or sharp webs of black, almost like fractals that were tearing themselves across the fields of red.

column16: I became slightly drowsy, and I might have slipped into more of a trance if I let myself.  I would periodically close my eyes or look away, reminding myself of what I was doing.  However, I think if I forced myself to keep watching, I might have been able to slip further into the illusion.

column10:
Flowing, shifting geometric patterns — most often V shapes, inverted Vs, rapidly spinning circles or spirals, or Xs — that sometimes seemed to expand beyond the edges of the monitor.
Occasionally, one of the patterns, especially the circles and spirals, would briefly register in my mind as a spinning circular room with elaborate columns around the periphery before I lost focus or had to blink and the image was gone.

column10:
I saw geometric shapes, mostly squares turned at a 45 degree angle, but sometimes five- or eight-sided.  The shapes generally looked like I was speeding into or out of a long tunnel, which curved in one direction.  Occasionally, the "tunnel" would suddenly stop and the whole image would spin on a vertical or horizontal axis so that I was looking at the "tunnel" from the side, then another shape would emerge.

On several occasions, I saw a more static geometric shape, like a pentagon with lines coming from the center out to each vertex, that would spin clockwise or counterclockwise, accelerating until the rotation blurred, and then the image would suddenly appear to be spinning in the opposite direction, slowing down until it stopped, then a new image would emerge.

On one instance, I saw what looked like a frog swimming down toward the bottom of the screen.

column10: I saw morphing, rolling, and spinning shapes not unlike a kaleidoscope (but only in black and red). Initial images were somewhat like a fanned out grid with a few long-spiked eight-point stars in various locations where grid lines connected. Several minutes into the Ganzflicker, and with harder concentration, the images on the screen began to spin or alternatively roll inward on themselves in the shape of the golden ratio. The images both moved of their own volition AND were moved along by my eyes trying to track them across the screen, which made it difficult to focus. Eventually the moving images led me to the edge of the screen and broke my concentration further. Other times when my eyes became unfocused, yet trained at the center of the screen, I thought I saw a rough outline of a neighborhood of rooftops. At a much later point, I could imagine myself spiraling through space along the edge of earth's atmosphere and towards the sun. This was by no means a clear picture though, because I feel like it was partially in my blind-ish mind's eye/imagination rather than on the screen, though I was definitely seeing some of the major shapes on the screen that then informed the imagining (It is very difficult to explain my mind's eye because I feel that it is 'neither here nor there'; I know it exists, yet I can't fully 'see' what I 'visualize' in my mind [yet I am an architect/design professional who successfully relies on my ability to conceptualize rooms and buildings in my mind before committing them to paper]. So the best was I can explain this is to say that I 'feel' things like shapes and ideas in my mind, in leiu of an active visual mind or constant stream of consiousness.).

column10: I saw pulsing geometric shapes, patterns, and waves. They were constantly moving. Mostly in red/gray/black, but a couple of times I saw green or blue as well. The pulsing patterns would be stable (not static, but pulsing regularly) for 5 - 10 seconds before morphing into something else. I wanted to pull the screen as close to my face as possible to try to enhance the effect. On a couple of occasions the visuals felt like "going through hyperspace", i.e. the patterns were pulsing in a way reminiscent of the hyperspace special effect found in movies like Star Wars. The patterns seemed to pause momentarily when I would blink, so I tried to avoid doing so.

column10: Immediately I saw colors of all kinds and it felt as if the screen was breathing. I found myself very interested in how the edges of the screen would turn white and move inward towards the center of the screen and imitated a sort of breathing motion. At one point I saw a ball of light and I imagined that it was on the end of a sort of magic wand and it moved all over the screen with no pattern whatsoever. I felt as though I was supposed to stay with it and train my eyes on the ball of light, following it as best I could. The ball of light was white with blue emanating from it almost like a shooting star or something you would see in space. I also felt a presence, almost like an energy in the flashing screen and it became quite comforting. I did feel myself wishing I had seen more and more clearly but most of what I did see felt abstract, including the shifting colors, shapes and then energies of the screen flashing. Throughout the experience, I had the sense that I was watching a story unfold, even though I had no context for said story. That is just what I felt.
column12: 1 or 2 times in the whole experience
column14: Persisting several seconds, Constant, morphing from one image to the next
column15: Relaxed but trance-like, focused & calm. It also felt like a really fast 10 mins!
column16: As I said above, I felt very relaxed but almost hypnotized and when the 10 minutes were up at felt like no time has passed at all. I found myself feeling pretty hyper-focused but not in an uncomfortable way. As I previously mentioned, I found myself wishing I was seeing more so I felt motivated to stay focused but I did my best to not let this pressure my experience. I felt excited and curious to try this and found myself intrigued and able to enjoy flashing screen even though it felt strange at first. I was surprised at how immediately calm I felt when the flashing started.

column10:
In the beginning I mostly saw black margins appearing on the borders of the screen, as it the display area was shrinking. The rest was mostly white/blue blobs or waves, curvy patterns changing regularly. But that was faint, I was totally conscious that I was looking at a red and black blinking screen, nothing felt vivid. Also after some time my entire field of vision was blinking, not just the screen.
For indication on my mind's eye, I have no trouble projecting myself visually in a book when I read, it's automatic. But I have troubles visualizing something in my head for more than a short moment, it's like snapshots.

column10: Initial imagery consisted of distortions, simple shapes/patterns, basic mechanisms and gears. Gradual increase in complexity and intensity; more intricate mechanisms with discrete components, "megastructures" in space, galaxies/vortices, occasional buildings, strange faces. As session continued, imagery tended to become more violent and disturbing -- clockwork mechanisms of many highly-detailed gears, axles, and pistons operating extremely quickly; monstrous, alien, or "demonic" faces, sometimes with many teeth, sometimes chewing, biting, or swallowing very violently (and sometimes from a perspective "within" the mouth and throat); suns/stars and other celestial bodies in plotted orbits, or accreting vortices ejecting plumes of matter; and more rarely, normal buildings or basic urban "environments"/settings.
column13: Clear, vivid, and/or bright, Images were very obviously not real in terms of colour or other components, but still highly detailed and "immersive"; black and red remained dominant colours and the images were typically too transient to form a comprehensive impression, but otherwise were vivid and intricate enough to seem realistic or "logical"

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black, Complex objects (e.g., animals, faces, buildings), Complex environments (e.g., cityscapes, forests), I don't know if this is a common experience, but it was like watching an animation but in slow motion. It reminded me of of when a roll of film starts and isn't quite up to speed so you can still see a quick flash in between each frame.
column10: Initially I began to see two black triangles one growing up from the bottom of the screen and the other descending from the top. They began to round out slightly and connected in the middle of the screen to create the silhouette of an hourglass. As the sand ran into the bottom of the hourglass it began to grow and sharpen. The perimeter of the screen flashed deep blue and the bottom half of the hourglass slowly transformed into huge black pyramid that seemed to glow yellow around the edges. Soon the angle began to change making the pyramid appearing to continue growing. I felt dwarfed in comparison. Eventually the pyramid grew large enough that it covered to whole screen. After that my eyes unfocused for a bit and it was just flashing but a moment or so later these abstract blobs appeared from the edges of the screen and began to float aimlessly combining when they bumped into each other and splitting apparently randomly. The blobs were all different colors but they seemed very desaturated while the background remained a very bright red. It had a similar effect to playing desaturated film or animation to denote a memory, or flashback and I gained the impression that I was looking at a ghost of an image. The blobs began moving to the right side of the screen and combining into one blob and turning a sort of cool gray color which slowly took the shape of a woman (from about mid-thigh to shoulders) facing the left side of the screen. The outline was wobbly and fluid at first as the blobs came together but they soon began to clarify as the movement shifted solely towards her stomach and she grew steadily pregnant. The background became a sort of desaturated greenish grey color and the woman's silhouette darkened considerably (but not to fully black). Everything slowly faded out and my eyes unfocused again. When they refocused I saw bright moving shapes and patterns similar to what I see when I close my eyes very tightly or press on them slightly. The patterns dissipated and made way for a black and white image of the pregnant woman from the mid-thigh up leaning against an ivy covered stone wall and looking out at a city skyline at sunset. Although the image itself was black and white, I got the distinct impression that the woman's hair (which was in a ponytail that ended just above the middle of her shoulders blades) was a light brown. Additionally, although I couldn't see much of her legs or her feet I'm pretty sure she wore leggings and ballet flats. At that point I wondered if I had any control over what I was seeing so I attempted to make the woman walk across the screen from left to right while trailing her hand lightly allow the wall. When this was successful I tried to make her walk back the other direction and found that this made the image "glitch" and that reverse her previous movement  as though I was hitting a rewind button or I could extend the landscape around her so that she could continue to walk towards the right but I couldn't make her walk from right to left. Once again, my eyes unfocused and the image disappeared. Now the screen became bright red again and images began to appear at the bottom of the screen (in the foreground) and slowly crawl upwards and fade into the background as new images came into view. They were all overlapping slightly and placed at various angles (a few were even upside down) each image seemed to be of a different place almost like they were postcards or old photos. Many of them were famous places like the statue of liberty, the Eiffel tower, the Taj mahalo, or the tower of Pisa. Others were less extravagant, such as a generic beach, a campsite in a forest, or an open air pavilion in a public park. These images were brighter than the the previous ones. They appeared in full color and while they weren't vivid as though they were real, it did feel a lot like looking through old family photos. From there my eyes unfocused one last time and it had been just over ten minutes.

column16: I might try doing this again at some point when I'm not on my adhd med because I feel like it kept me tethered to reality a bit during this and kept me more aware than I might otherwise be, but it felt a lot like meditation. I was very calm and relaxed and I allowed my thoughts to wander wherever they pleased but once I noticed they were wandering too far I gently brought myself back to the ganzflicker. It did also remind me quite a bit of when I'm in an art flow and I'm simply creating mostly unconsciously while my thoughts meander until I suddenly stumble upon some ideas for something I want to try (like making the woman walk across the screen) and shift into a more acute focus with conscious movements and decisions before eventually slipping back into the flow of doing whatever feels right an naturally without thinking too much.

column10: Initially it was rows of boxes flickering, those boxes kept morphing into rectangles and other similar 4 sided shapes with soft edges defined by the red/bluish black.  The flickering would seemingly change in speed and almost pulse at times.  There was a pink "line" that almost looked like a cut or scar that would cut thru spaces between the shapes, sometimes skinny and solid, others thicker with > shape lines pointing along its long ends.  The screen would seem to grow and shift in size, never to smaller than its physical size.  It would seem to move with my eyes, but never really leave its real/physical footprint.  Towards the end a small perfect circle showed up that would move around with my gaze, slowly rings appeared outside it, then the circles were highlighted in neon green, it looked like a reflection of light from inside the smallest circle that shifted as it all moved.  At the start I had a momentary overwhelmed feeling, but that lasted less than 5 seconds and never returned.  I remained interested and curious about what would happen.

Interconnected pentagons, octagons, etc.  I then began to see spiral galaxies, often tilted at 45 degrees in my center of vision.  These would morph and change shape and position. It was very easy to lose track of time.  If my email hadn't gotten my attention, I wouldn't have looked away.  It felt difficult to not look at the screen.

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black
column10: Lots of movement like gears, moving mechanically but in a fluid way. Lots of grids moving in spirals. The first thing I noticed was a grid with four sections, split up by four lines that met in the middle around a circle. It wasn't an evenly spaced grid, it looked more like a cross or a window with the light coming through the frame instead of the panes. This grid came back to me the most throughout. I got a lot of flashes of green at the beginning and had some yellow and blue flashes as well. The color variations lessened as it went on and it became mostly red. Sometimes the peripherals would get this spider web effect and warp inwards. Most of the images were centrally located but the times that I focused less, I saw more pulsing chaos, fuzzy forms bouncing horizontally.

column16: As soon as it started it's like I couldn't stop looking at it. I felt very focused and although it was like my observing brain was very active, it felt like my thinking brain was zoned out. I did not notice that I had any distracting thoughts and did not agonize over sitting still for 10 minutes. I actually felt very still. I was sitting on the couch while watching and noticed my feet started to tingle a bit.

Same thing with a series of lines and bubbles moving up from the bottom of the screen, like flowers growing. The patterns did grow a bit more vivid as time went on, but seemed to hit a plateau after about 5 minutes. I was getting irritated so I stopped.

column9: Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black, Complex objects (e.g., animals, faces, buildings), spinning fractal images
column10: Mostly I saw a bunch of red lights battling each other: whipping by in swirls, smacking into white balls of light, flashing out like fans of lasers. I saw a lot of spinning fractal images and patterns, like through a kaleidoscope (they were mostly red, white, and blue). Early on the fractals were entirely line and shape patterns, but towards the end they developed complex and vivid textures like bubbles and feathers and honeycombs - it was more like looking at a painting as opposed to my computer screen, but it was isolated to a small corner. Sometimes there was a black-and-white animation on the edge of my vision, but it was moving too quickly for me to make out. I thought it looked like an old Mickey Mouse cartoon at one point. I also faintly saw Simpsons characters. Would you consider spinning galaxies complex environments? They didn't seem that exciting, because they were all in red and white. I saw a simple stick figure riding a bike, kicking a ball, things like that - the figure was blurry, definitely in there but not clear. Eventually, I saw a rainbow! There was more, but these are the things that stand out.
column14: Constant, morphing from one image to the next
column15: Lost a sense of time, I dissociated frequently, and found I could stay in a gray-ed out state of consciousness if I chose too.
column16: I set two timers for this: one for ten minutes, and another for twenty. I didn't hear either of them (headphones worked better than I thought), and what I thought had been 15 minutes was actually 30. As for dissociation, it would happen every time I stopped concentrating - my vision would get softer and I'd zone out. This didn't surprise me, I expect these sorts of activities to trigger my dissociative disorder. What did surprise me was that I could catch myself dissociating, then stay in the gray zone (aware of my surroundings but my vision still in soft focus) apparently as long as I chose. I tried to stay grounded, though, and I think the most interesting images occurred when I felt I was fully alert.

column10: Mostly indistinct lines, curves, and blobs. For the last few minutes there was a static flame pattern along the bottom periphery, and a flashing, blurry line down the middle from top to bottom. Most remarkable was actually when I turned the flicker off: for a few seconds, I saw very clear swirls on the whole screen (the dark gray background of the page that played the white noise), all about the size of a half-dollar, swirling in and out of each other. These were much more clear and fluid than anything I saw during the Ganzflicker. This effect persisted for just a few seconds.

column10: Multiple colors. Radiating 360 degrees from a center were thin lines that occupied about 1/6 of the computer screen that seem to have shifted from white at first changing to black toward the end. Each line was a zig zag with a long radial line from center outward and then a short line at 90 degrees and then continues on as a long radial line away from the center.
column14: Overall pattern was constant yet changing in detail .
column15: I shifted my attention inward to allow the flickering light to wash over me.
column16: I distanced myself from the changing flickering light and felt a solid unchanging sense of self that was my core being. I could have continued, but, there was a concern as my body temperature rose that it may not be in my best interest to do so. I wondered that if thru a brain event like a stroke I saw this visual for the rest of my life...could I cope.  That solid core of self said maybe. I pondered if I could sufficiently put distance between that unchanging sense of self and the unrelenting stimulation to body and mind. Could that stimulation become background noise before I went crazy?  The experiment is over and I am content to go back to my everyday consciousness knowing that I am not the body and I am not even the mind... I am something more permanent than either.

column10: started with an X image in the screen. It was kind of like it was being drawn on the screen with 2 quick downward slashes. Then that kind of changed into a hallway. The "bubbles" were interesting but fleeting. It seemed as though if I moved my eyes the effect on the screen would change from the spiraling, slashes, grid, boiling, and hallway. Lots of interesting visuals. I didn't seem to see things coming "out of the screen" but I felt like I was seeing "into" the screen.

column10: The dominant color was a bluish black, and the red became an orange color, like a barely remaining sunset. I mostly saw spiral shapes... like pinwheels that would appear to be spinning quickly but would slow down and tilt and eventually disappear until my brain "caught" the next one. It was sort of like waiting to see a shooting star, catching it, then watching it disappear. After about 15 minutes I started to see a landscape. Trees on an embankment near a body of water at sunset, sort of blurry and barely visible.

column16: I thought that if I did not have the timer of the white noise interval of ten minutes, more time could easily have passed and I might have lost track. It felt much more brief than 20 minutes. column10: The experience was as if I was looking out a window onto a blizzard at night, I guess. The flickering took the form of snowy wind, swirling in a chaotic manner. To clarify, I didn’t see anything like a snowy, night scene. I didn’t see a window, a window frame, an outdoor setting, snow, or wind. It’s just that the flickering was reminiscent of blizzard-y wind filling the whole volume of a natural space. I did see, however, pinpoints of yellowy green light that swirled about the flickering red/black field of my phone screen in a manner akin to blowing of fine snow in a blizzard. So, to clarify further, the yellowy green pinpoints swirled, as did the red/black flickering itself. At a couple of moments in the experience, the pinpoints of yellowy green light seemed to lift out of the screen a bit, but just a bit. I should also add that in the first few minutes the flickering not only swirled but also rolled, sometimes up to down and other times down to up, as a reel of film moving quickly through a projector and across a screen. This “cinematic” rolling also seemed to move sideways at times, but it was hard to distinguish this sideways rolling motion from the more evident up/down and down/up rolling.
column11: I don’t think I saw images, per se. I saw pinpoints of light and non-flickering motion in the main.

column9: Distortions (e.g., screen warping or rotating), Simple shapes or patterns (e.g., ball of light, lines, grids, spiderwebs, geometric shapes), Colors other than red and black, Complex objects (e.g., animals, faces, buildings), Words and letters: 'Freezer', 'Colonel', 'STOP', 'g', 'w', 'y', 'TWIN',' 1', 'cheese', 'Freezer', 'READ', 'wethepeople', 'G'
column10: The screen always seemed like it was bouncing. It switched back and forth between having weird lines (usually appearing pink, teal, or yellow), and concentric shapes (usually triangles). The first things I noticed (almost immedietly) were the words 'Colonel' and 'Freezer'. A minute later, the word 'STOP' appeared, this one had a clearly noticeable font that was large and with sans. The letters had a white outline, and whitish stripes going from bottom left to top right. The word 'TWIN' was more yellowish, though most of the others were just a vague discoloration that I can't describe very well, although most of them appeared to be in a font with sans (the letter G was the only one without sans, and I couldn't really decide if it was actually a G or just a thin yellow swirl). 'wethepeople' was in a very bold/fat font, with letters as wide as they were tall. The letters were also all smushed together. Throughout my time watching the Ganzflicker, I also saw eyes (which moved about the screen and occasionally blinked), a shape similar to the pokemon Espeon, and deer antlers.

column17: All over the screen, Various spots. The word 'Colonel' appeared in the top left of the screen. 'Freezer' appeared in the top right. 'TWIN' appeared in the center (a smidge to the left). 'wethepeople' appeared across the bottom

column10:
Typical visual "strobing", limited to the screen. Light blue and dark blue instead of black. Looked like the way movies portray the process of switching bodies (going through this weird tube thing like on That's So Raven). I saw impressions of the way audio tracks are visualized (google audio track clip art).
I also saw several horizon lines. First, the silhouette of a pine forest at night. During this I saw a tiny, faint moon rise and fall. Then I saw a shadowy apple move across the screen. I saw the trees maybe twice more, the last time including their reflection on a lake. I also saw the ocean horizon. All of this was pretty faint, though.

In my periphery, I sometimes saw red or yellow chairs doing much the same. Much of the time, I thought I saw eyes bouncing on the screen, sometimes connected to stalks. the flashing also seemed to slow down quite a bit.

column10:
Almost the whole experience had a sense of moving backgrounds, like a drone flying around an environment. Sometimes it would be steady and sort of "fly over the environment", other times it would move/rotate around complexly (it did not feel like I was a drone, I am instead trying to describe the movement of my "vision" of the backgrounds).

Occasionally I would see a human figure, but it never resolved into anything particularly vivid.

There were a number of times it felt like I could very vividly see a human face (not attached to the figures described above), but it would melt fairly rapidly into a moving background.

Lots of the more vivid experience felt like natural objects; trees, oceans, forests, rivers, etc. Occasionally something more man-made would emerge, but a majority of the experience looked "natural".

column10: As the screen flickered at first I saw nothing. Then as my eyes relaxed I began to retain after-images of each flash. After about a minute of relaxing these after-images began to take shape into various patterns, almost like the audio visualizers on the old Windows Media Player only the images were always monochromatic (though that singular color would shift within the red/yellow spectrum as I gazed). These patterns would pulse and move/shake with a sort of rhythm before either fading back into nothingness or turning into something else. In the most intense moments, the imagery started as shapes but turned into moving images that felt like flip books. One appeared to be a first-person perspective moving forward along the wires of some bridge high in the air, and another seemed to be hurtling past stars. No other explicit imagery comes to mind, though a feeling of forward motion was a constant after the first few seconds. Whenever my eyes would get dry or tired, however (as I wear contact lenses), they would refocus and the image would disappear and a new one would begin as my eyes relaxed again.

Generally I felt kind of out of it, like being in the fog after waking up from NyQuil, although in a more positive/active and engaged way.

column10: At first a black and red flicker, then various patterns of shapes began to emerge and pulsate. The colors changed to yellow/white/orange with the pulsating shapes patterns and specks of blue and green patterns emerging. At some points the entire screen looked like it was moving around drawing itself as it moved about. At other points it looked like moving through a 3D tunnel and road still in the same colors not real world colors, like a video game almost. Then around the nine/ten minute mark the screen went completely black but the patterns and shapes continued very vividly emerging almost out of the edges of the screen for a few moments and it looked almost like I was standing inside my eyes looking out before I realized the screen had turned off. At that point I clicked the track pad to wake up the computer and saw the red and black flicker again which almost immediately started pulsating with patterns of shapes again while I watched for about another minute or so before turning it off.

column10:
At first it was slightly unpleasant, but I think that might have been because my eyes were adjusting to the lower light conditions as I turned off the lights to do this. So at first I didn't see much. But as I relaxed I saw patterns. Swirling that was clockwise in direction. I saw lots of dots swirling, first small then bigger. 

At one time the patterns formed into what looks like a big caterpillar crawling across the screen, but I wouldn't say it was definitely a caterpillar, more of a pattern/swirl that looked somewhat like a caterpillar. 

I found half way through that I could blink rapidly and I would see either the red or the black flash, and if I blinked with the right frequency I would see only black or only red for a few seconds. After doing this for a few seconds it seemed that the patterns would start after being gone for a minute or so, or would appear more vivid.

column16: My wife is in the other room so at first I was a little nervous that she might come in and think what I was doing was quite odd. But after a couple minutes I relaxed and didn't think about that. The experience made me feel relaxed and overall I thought it was enjoyable, but after answering the above questions I'm a little disappointed that I didn't see or hear anything more concrete. During the experience it was interesting to see the shapes form and move around on the screen.

column10: At first the pattern was jarring, but as I eased into it I observed the following. The screen morphed from a simple uniform flicker to a pulsing emanating from top to bottom. this eventually morphed to be different parts were either on or off at the same time. At first the red pulsed in a circle similar to "jumpin' jackpot", before becoming splotches. From then on, by relaxing, the imagery was about as in depth as the after-image from a too-bright room, occasionally "popping-out" of the screen in the way the "magic eye" books work.  most of the imagery was focused around the center of my vision, things like balls and blobs, but later on morphed into a larger and larger revolving sphere of honeycomb, slowly increasing in size until the edge of the sphere became the horizon of a planet, in a sci-fi way, but again, no greater clarity than a combination after-image/magic eye. The whole experience reminded me of the closed-eye hallucinations I get when I'm very sleep deprived. I could relax into it, or snap out of it, but I never felt rewarded or punished for it.

column10: At first, I just saw black and red screens flickering, but eventually it was like I could see blues/deep blue-greens, with occasional hints of oranges or yellows. The screen seemed to pulsate. Eventually, it was like I could see streams of circles moving around the screen. At first, these seemed to be circles falling down the screen, but eventually they seemed to transition to the screen spinning in an anti-clockwise motion around what seemed to be a central circle. I then wondered if I could consciously make the screen spin in a clockwise motion, and after thinking about it for about 5-10 seconds, I found I could switch between the two (anti-clockwise versus clockwise) easily. At some point, it then looked like the screen was following lines downward. I again tried to imagine if I could make the lines to upward, and I could. I was surprised that I could exert some sort of conscious control over what I was seeing. Eventually, my eyes just started to grow fatigued and uncomfortable. I didn't see anything else other than that described above.

column10: At first, I saw long streaks moving like snakes. They slithered like a snake, and they were moving in 3 dimensions (maybe like a snake or an eel swimming). I also saw long lines of spheres moving in swirling motions. Almost like a whirlpool. I tried make certain images appear by thinking about them. I made several eyes appear, but I only saw one at a time. Each eye looked a bit different than the last. I think all the images were white with a red background.

column10:
At first, there were black geometric shapes and blue patterns (fractal-like, like the Mandelbrot set). A few seconds later, green "trails" started to appear.
After some time, cyan trails appeared. At approximately the same time, my geometric shapes started getting more complex and detailed, very much like in hypnagogic hallucinations before falling asleep.
Just like with these, my shapes started turning into complex objects and orange and blue trails slowly appeared. These objects were morphing and moving, I could describe them as feathers, fabrics, silhouettes of people, wood...
Some of these followed my center of vision. And there was an orange dot in it, right at the center.

Blue lines, two of them most of the time, they were usually in a cross across the whole screen and they were laid upon one other. The bottom one often started rotating and the whole space inside the screen rotated with it, while the upper one stayed stationary.
